componenttextpreview: Sorry, I understood that the question was another. You're right, Ottavio, sorry, sorry. So yes, you're right. This deal, the Bouygues deal, 500 towers, is a split in 2 parts now, 230 and 270 towers. And the economical terms comparing the EBITDA contributi
componenttext: Sorry, I understood that the question was another. You're right, Ottavio, sorry, sorry. So yes, you're right. This deal, the Bouygues deal, 500 towers, is a split in 2 parts now, 230 and 270 towers. And the economical terms comparing the EBITDA contribution and the enterprise value are similar. So yes, it is [indiscernible] I thought you were asking for [indiscernible]. But the answer is, this 500 towers are coherent in terms of the relationship between the EBITDA contribution and then the [indiscernible] value required by the [indiscernible]. So the second question talks about Page 23. Of course, you know, Ottavio, that personally, I monitor the market on a daily basis and [indiscernible] every step you can see how the green line is typing and is getting more nearer now to our benchmark. And just, of course, I think that Cellnex has to keep an eye on it, and as soon as the market might be open or might be one in an attractive condition for us because of the market is open. So now it is a question of [indiscernible], a question of when. We will be, for sure, really to fund the company not because we need it because we [indiscernible] need it. I mean, we are not in a rush. But just on opportunistic basis to capture maybe a bond, a long-term bond that allow us to look at low interest rate for a very long term, and therefore, be more value accretive when we acquire a company. So yes, the answer is yes, we are monitoring the market. Also, your third question was regarding CommsCon. So in order to answer that question may be we can go to Page 25. So in Page 25, we will have to try to represent a little bit business model of CommsCon now. And there are 3 boxes: venue owners; Cellnex, where we do with CommsCon now; and our customers. If you follow this graph, you will see that Cellnex pays a rental fee to the venue owner, to make it very simple. And Cellnex deploys CapEx and incurs the OpEx of managing the system. And as a consequence of this, we receive money, a fee by the MNO. So obviously, the EUR 1.5 million EBITDA, how sustainable it is? We'll think it is sustainable. We'll think it is going to grow in the future. And look at something here. The fees that they may not pay to us has 2 parts. The first part is stagnant -- initially stagnant or after the consideration for the infrastructure that will build up for the system. And second, we'll receive different installments for a long of time, so enough from consolidation and then long-term payments. Therefore, we'll think that this EUR 1.5 million is sustainable and as the market develops -- because in Europe, the opportunity is massive. All of us would have gone to put a very simple example. In London, now when you go London Lounge and maybe you have progress in order to send a WhatsApp in order to go on with a conversation. And so as this situation in London, there are many other situation in Europe. And we think that with CommsCon, we are very well placed in order to improve this coverage and to fill in these gaps. And finally, the fourth question, maybe Alex you can help me. Already, Ottavio, you can repeat it, because -- but I don't know, I mean, Alex as you wish.

On the top of the sites that other MNO [indiscernible] might be offering to the new entity. headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for taking my questions. I've got just, what, let's say, 3 one -- 3 short ones. Well, the first one is on the mobile backhaul. You said in the past that you have sort of demands from a number of clients regarding that opportunity. I know for a f
componenttext: Thank you for taking my questions. I've got just, what, let's say, 3 one -- 3 short ones. Well, the first one is on the mobile backhaul. You said in the past that you have sort of demands from a number of clients regarding that opportunity. I know for a fact that one of the clients is very, very keen on such an idea. But maybe can you give us maybe good color about the sort of breadth of the demand that you're seeing, both in Italy and Spain. And maybe add a little bit of sort of economics of the -- all this opportunity. My second question is more of a sort of long-term structural one. Looking at your new markets, both Netherlands and France, do you see sort of a change in shift regarding willingness of MNOs to dispose of the towers? I mean, we know that we've sold in France, we know that [indiscernible] sold in France. We know that KPN sold in that business a while back. But there have been more or less kind of keeping the towers on the books. Do you see if there are any shifts there we should be aware of? And my third question [indiscernible] one, regarding sort of the Telecom Italia's development of new towers with Inwit, will there be any competitive pressure on you immediately? I presume it's no, but just want to make sure that's the case.

I just want to know if there'll be any competitive pressure on you because of that. I mean, I presume that's not the case, but just want to make sure.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So okay, understood. No -- yes, to answer this question, no, no, we have no pressure -- more pressure because of this announcement. And we said before, we're going with our own plan. We have seen that our strategy is the right one. We are independent comp
componenttext: So okay, understood. No -- yes, to answer this question, no, no, we have no pressure -- more pressure because of this announcement. And we said before, we're going with our own plan. We have seen that our strategy is the right one. We are independent company. So we have to follow working with our different clients on a neutral basis. So no, we keep on working, okay? Regarding your second question, the disposal of towers and if there is any change now in the attitude. This is -- Cellnex is a long-term investor and is a long-term player. So we don't think that in the short term, in one quarter to the other quarter, things are going to be from black to white or from white to black, no. We -- I think that we're working a lot with many European MNOs. We are trying to explain our business model to bring to the table the benefits of it. And obviously, as a result of this work, step-by-step very progressively, things will change, and for instance, had a change in France for us with this opportunity, which we think is very important and significant. But no, you will never change -- big changes from one thing to the other. However, this is our gradual working, which we are very well positioned. And finally, regarding the first question, I would like maybe Alex, you can help us.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to complete the last one, I think there is an important issue maybe to emphasize. Which I am [indiscernible] is that, José Manuel, that have not been disposing towers, there is still, I believe, that tower is a critical technical asset. So probably
componenttext: Just to complete the last one, I think there is an important issue maybe to emphasize. Which I am [indiscernible] is that, José Manuel, that have not been disposing towers, there is still, I believe, that tower is a critical technical asset. So probably the first department that has to be convinced in order to go in this direction that financially could make sense  is the technical department. Then we speak the technical language. And as industrial player, for us, it's not difficult, let's say, to tune the frequencies, because we talk about frequencies -- keeping the frequencies with our counterparties in the technical departments of [indiscernible] it can establish a comfort, let's say, discussion that could, let's say, lower those entry barriers that maybe is another type of potential where you're more financially responsible, another kind of interested party to either towers could be a little bit more difficult. So we believe that as industry player, we have essential technical advantage there on having this technical-to-technical discussion. On your first question, which was these mobile backhaul. Yes, this is true. So densification, more technologies in a single tower means more bandwidth. And more frequencies per tower means more bandwidth to be delivered to each tower. Then normally, this is done by Microweb. So radio links, there is no fiber. However, the demand of these more bandwidth requires, in many cases, to substitute the radio links with fiber. And this is a process where all of the MNOs are as of today investing or continuing to invest in the coming years. Specifically, we were allowed to offer 4G, [indiscernible] that requirement are much more demanding. Our interest there is because we believe that this backhaul can be neutralized. So there is no strategic advantage, let's say, on that. And the fact of having a CapEx that could be neutralized it is very much what is our business about. And our intention is to stay at the dark fiber level. So it means we are not intending to enter into optical electronics, into connectivity, which sometimes changes a little the profile of the operation and maintenance of this type of agreement. So we intend to stay on the dark fiber, let's say, layer of value proposition to the MNOs. And in relation to the economics, this may be very different on depending where the tower is, as you can imagine, and how far is the main backhaul is far from the tower, because then you need to do some sort of construction to build from the backbone to the tower some CapEx there, could be 30 meters, could be 3 kilometers. So that, as you can imagine, is going to depend very, very much. And the idea is to understand the needs of the MNOs. In Italy, we have around 15% of our towers with fiber, so there is [indiscernible] very, very clear. And now with the new MNO potential, this neutralization effect that we were mentioning is much more obvious. So we believe that the opportunities are clearly there. There is a small budget that we're doing in Italy on that in the range of, let's say, dozens of towers to put fiber on our side. This is helping us to understand also the retail economy [indiscernible] the complexity of doing that. Based on that, we will, let's say, take a more stern step towards putting fiber to our towers. We see the fiber to the towers like the roots of a tree. When you have these roots, it's more difficult to move the tower. So also in terms of long-term sustainability of the contracts, we believe that it's also bringing value on the top of that.

componenttext: In fact, it is true that we -- I have been talking today -- I had been focusing on cash advance. But it is true that today, you only have [indiscernible]. componenttext: My first question is on your recent acquisitions in the Netherlands, France and Italy. Can you give an indication on when they will become accretive from an earnings per share point of view? And the second question is on possible future M&A. Now if in one of the markets where you are present, if you have the opportunity to acquire, control other towers operator, which is primarily broadcasting but also with telco towers, would that be an appealing opportunity for you? And my third question is maybe going back to the DAS, if you can maybe give us an idea on the profitability in terms of EBITDA margin and top line revenue growth rate, please.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Luigi, thank you very much for your questions. Regarding your first question, which was the accretive impact of these acquisitions on recurring levered free cash flow. And the answer, I think we [indiscernible] we can go to base testing [indiscernib
componenttext: Okay. Luigi, thank you very much for your questions. Regarding your first question, which was the accretive impact of these acquisitions on recurring levered free cash flow. And the answer, I think we [indiscernible] we can go to base testing [indiscernible] you can see here, the EBITDA that on a ground rate basis we expect from this period for 2017. So -- and after that, we deduct the maintenance CapEx, the taxes, the working capital, the interest expenses. And therefore, after this EBITDA is converted into recurring levered free cash flow, so the thing is that out of these EUR 14,5 million of EBITDA that we are acquiring, we convert into cash flow for our shareholders EUR 12 million. So we do think that it is a very high conversion ratio. And we can't do that, because we have a very strict policy in terms of maintenance CapEx and working capital. And we do -- we try -- we structure all the transactions in a way that from a DAS perspective, we can be competitive. And also as we were speaking before, from an interest expense perspective, we are opportunistic and we take advantage to fund these transactions in a very competitive way. So the answer is yes, these transactions are accretive from day 1, so we don't have to wait 2 or 3 years to see the cash flow per share to be increased. 2017 and even 2016, the recurring levered free cash flow per share will be increased because of these transactions. Your second question will be -- if I recall, it was regarding M&A, when M&A is considering telco broadcasting opportunities altogether. As you can read in our IOM and also in the [indiscernible], you will see that we clearly state that our objective is to step by step increase our exposure to Telecom Site Rental. It is true that also if in order to do so we have to acquire broadcasting, we might assess the opportunity. But that will not be an end [indiscernible] to get what we want on which we are focused, which is the Telecom Site Rental business. So this is the reality, focus on Telecom Site Rental. And your last question, which I think is EBITDA growth of DAS, I think maybe Alex, you can help us a little bit here.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. [indiscernible] the question was often also related on the economics of those projects. So as José Manuel was saying, Page 25 [indiscernible] a little bit how DAS work. There is one key element that makes those project, let's say, different project-
componenttext: Yes. [indiscernible] the question was often also related on the economics of those projects. So as José Manuel was saying, Page 25 [indiscernible] a little bit how DAS work. There is one key element that makes those project, let's say, different project-by-project can be categorized in different type of projects. And then, of course, economics may change, especially in relation to the investment. So in many cases, if the venue owner who is [indiscernible] investment, because it brings more [indiscernible] of the venue, because it is -- the owner of the big volume that wants to [indiscernible] coverage, so as you can imagine, those projects where there is some CapEx already being deployed by the venue owner are different than the ones that we need to go through the MNOs, convincing them that it is worth to use some CapEx there and then get the critical mass to roll out the project with [indiscernible] and then other [indiscernible] and also having some sort of revenue share if there is one initial [indiscernible]. It is a mix of different models that, to be very honest, we are now understanding -- starting to understand  the complexity. And that's the reason that we acquired the company, which is very much specialized on that niche market. And the key element here is now to try to industrialize a little bit all those concepts and going beyond Italy or more than Italy where these company has been more or less having their commercial activity, going beyond on a difficult culture [indiscernible] try to adapt the model and being able to, let's say, achieve what we are [indiscernible] in the presentation to be a DAS leader operator in Europe. And this is our ambition, and we believe that with all this knowledge that we are acquiring [indiscernible] that we can move forward this process. As of today, some of those DAS elements the only way of being deployed are among in and of themselves. And sometimes, the [indiscernible], let's say, some time to market constraints. So we believe that being the independent player, we can catalyze and enable those projects in a faster way that until now we have somehow, let's say, delayed in time.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll try to. I think it is important to maybe do a little bit [indiscernible] on what is the active equipment that we deploy on the DAS. We do not deploy the base station, so the [indiscernible] architecture, and if you go to Page 25, it is clear on
componenttext: Yes, I'll try to. I think it is important to maybe do a little bit [indiscernible] on what is the active equipment that we deploy on the DAS. We do not deploy the base station, so the [indiscernible] architecture, and if you go to Page 25, it is clear on the central picture. And still you see that on the left side of the central picture, there are a few equipments, those are the DTS. So the equipment -- typical equipment that goes into the tower is this one, the one which is on the left, which is the #1, #2 and #3. This -- CapEx in this period from the MNO. So we are not entering, let's say, on to the active equipment at the complexity of a base station. What we do is this DTH [indiscernible] and the nodes and the fiber, we get the signal and the acronym tries to explain what it is. It is a digital [indiscernible] antenna. So we get the signal from DTS and we spread it through a wide coverage area. Instead of having 1 antenna each, for very node we put 10 to 15 antennas. That's the reason that as of today we have something like 900, almost 1,000 nodes, and every node is having 10 to 12 antennas. That's the reason we have up to 12,000 antennas in those systems overall as of today coming from the CommsCon acquisition. So the complexity of sharing the antenna is much less than the complexity of sharing the active agreement. Which then becomes a rank sharing sort of asking. So here, we are not talking about sharing the radio station, we just sharing a distributed antenna which being difficult to deploy in a venue like a stadium, for the [indiscernible] is probably the best way to do it or the only way is to do by sharing. That's the reason that most of the DAS systems as of today are starting from a shared system among different [indiscernible]. But they need to agree amongst themselves to do that. And maybe one has more intelligent in one area, the other in the other, so acting as an enabler of that process makes the situation easier, and where we believe we can get, let's say, an expansion of that business model to other areas. That is not -- it's different electronics, I don't know if I was clear myself. And what maybe your second question that I am not answering or did I answer everything?

And we do think that eventually that -- no, that finally we're carry, and we're doing good progress, even though slowly than expected. Why slowly? Because, I mean, the [indiscernible] is open in the market is -- and this requires times, requires the [indiscernible] angles to be patient. And I think as a long-term player, we are very well positioned to capture this market opportunity.

componenttext: Okay, yes. So the answer is yes, we think it's prudent, we think it makes sense. And if possible, this is our preferred strategy.

We have generated 415 new PoPs in 2016. 189 have been generated in Spain and 226 having been generated in Italy. So roughly equally split between the 2 geographies where we are already present.

componenttextpreview: Yes, in relation to the fourth. So seems that the #4 is the magic number now. So -- and logically and we have been always configuring, even at the moment that we acquired Galata in Italy, we had, in the back of our mind, the possibility of marriage betwee
componenttext: Yes, in relation to the fourth. So seems that the #4 is the magic number now. So -- and logically and we have been always configuring, even at the moment that we acquired Galata in Italy, we had, in the back of our mind, the possibility of marriage between 2 operators. And we'd like to protect ourselves [indiscernible]. And we always consider it in our business scale, there could be a consolidation, any further consolidation from 4 to 3. However, it seems that this is not going to be the case. And Jonathan, you're absolutely right that this brings consolidation opportunity that in many cases has not been authorized. And it is very much welcome from the perspective of the other TowerCo operator. Having said that, let's see how that evolves, okay? Let's see that finally it gets approval in Italy. Also, what we foresee in those additional countries where we are is that there is, yes, a challenger that needs to rapidly withdraw coverage and most likely trust to do on their own, because the grant-sharing agreement and growing an [indiscernible] revenue is easy. So for us, yes, it brings in additional that we are doing, let's say, [indiscernible] in order to capture.

componenttextpreview: The PoP growth in France, as of today, the MNOs we [indiscernible] split the country in 2. We have densely population area and non-dense population area. Dense population area is 42% approximately of the population, and the non-dense 57%. On the non-dense
componenttext: The PoP growth in France, as of today, the MNOs we [indiscernible] split the country in 2. We have densely population area and non-dense population area. Dense population area is 42% approximately of the population, and the non-dense 57%. On the non-dense, this is where the rent-sharing agreements are put in place, for instance, between the telecom and [indiscernible]. In the non-dense -- in the dense area, there are on rent-sharing agreements. But when you view on this dense areas, the number of towers, there is clearly a bigger spread between [indiscernible] who is the operator who has, let's say, the most number of the towers. And then the other MNOs can, in different levels of deployment of sites. And I think you're pointing rightly that it may be having an interest, and this is what we've been also able to discuss during the process -- recent process that we have with them in relation to building more sites, on one side and also Iliad and understanding also that there are some relatively [indiscernible] agents that for them to finish, let's say, national agreements also to deploy their own network on these areas. So yes, it is another opportunity in terms of having new tenancy in especially on these dense areas.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Basically, the interest is to learn on this slightly different market. And as you called, this could be expanded, because yes, we feel, let's say, in our market analysis, the demand for densification. And then maybe [indiscernible] results were to differe
componenttext: Basically, the interest is to learn on this slightly different market. And as you called, this could be expanded, because yes, we feel, let's say, in our market analysis, the demand for densification. And then maybe [indiscernible] results were to differentiate between that and the small cells. Small cells is a very small densification. As we try to explain in our documentation, it is a distributed antenna where the densification is something different. In terms of deployment, what we believe is that there is, as of today, an immediate need of DAS for densification. But small cells may come in ways a little bit further down the road, because that is quite also another type of equipment, small cells are still yet to be fully prepared by vendors in the full capacity of sharing among different MNOs. So we understand that there is that demand beyond Italy. And there -- it will come in other ways [indiscernible] with the small cells. So we can differentiate slightly between these 2 technologies.

I guess, the question is could you enter new markets building out DAS systems, DAS nodes? Or will it more be where you already have micro sites? And also, could you do those greenfields in new markets, or is it more like you'll buy -- or acquire existing operators?

componenttext: Okay. Yes, there is a question. And it is a debate that we've been having internally, because there are not that many companies like CommsCon. So as I said before, this is normally an agreement project-by-project phenomenon. So it is interestingly an area where we could grow a lot our activity potentially, considering the engineering capacity of designing projects and that CommsCon is having, however, it is clear that we intend to, let's say, drill out for this kind of services where our footprint is in the countries where we have presence, because the final relationship with them is already being established in those countries where we have micro cells. But you need to understand fully better the capacities of CommsCon. It is just a few weeks with us in order to see whether it makes sense to go beyond that. I don't know, José Manuel, if you want to evolve a little bit on...

componenttextpreview: I've seen that -- yes, you're right, Alex. We have [indiscernible] here internally. But my feeling and yes, talking about my view on this is that this is a huge market. There are a lot of opportunities, and obviously, CommsCon is an Italian market that is
componenttext: I've seen that -- yes, you're right, Alex. We have [indiscernible] here internally. But my feeling and yes, talking about my view on this is that this is a huge market. There are a lot of opportunities, and obviously, CommsCon is an Italian market that is starting with in Italy. But I'm pretty sure that we will expand the footprint very soon to at least Spain, France and the Netherlands with a very positive result. The clients that CommsCon has today are, in the [indiscernible] presentation stadiums, even Ikeas, and hotels. So it's massive, and it's massive, the venues on which CommsCon can provide services. So lot of value to create for us.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just follow up on that, because I guess, there is clear first-mover advantage? I mean, once someone signed an agreement to provide the DAS system in a venue, that's it. So I mean, when you think about it, like Ikea, why couldn't you, for example, si
componenttext: Can I just follow up on that, because I guess, there is clear first-mover advantage? I mean, once someone signed an agreement to provide the DAS system in a venue, that's it. So I mean, when you think about it, like Ikea, why couldn't you, for example, sign the European-wide agreement with Ikea? Because in the end, once you've signed up that venue, the mobile operators need to go with you. And you know Vodafone, I guess, from Italy and maybe Spain. So It's not -- I guess, it's more venue-based than kind of built-to-suite, because everyone would want to be in those high-capacity areas at some point.

componenttext: Okay, I think there is no more questions. But before ending the conversation, I would like to highlight one very more important conclusion. headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan,Head of the Investor Relations at Cellnex. I'm joined today by Alex Mestre, International Business Development Director; and José Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director, and who will lead today's presentation
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan,
Head of the Investor Relations at Cellnex. I'm joined today by Alex Mestre, International Business Development Director; and José Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director, and who will lead today's presentation. I would like to thank you for joining us today for Cellnex H1 2016 Results Conference Call. We have, earlier today, posted a presentation, which we will refer to throughout our prepared remarks under the Investor Relations section on our website. And then we'll open the line for a Q&A session.
So now I'll hand over to José Manuel. Please, José Manuel.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you so much for your time today. And please allow me to start by highlighting the main milestones of the period. We are in Page 4. Here, you can see that today, we're presenting again a solid set of results that confirm the market ex
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you so much for your time today. And please allow me to start by highlighting the main milestones of the period. We are in Page 4. Here, you can see that today, we're presenting again a solid set of results that confirm the market expectations for the period. We have also resume our M&A activity by executing 2 value-accretive deals, while establishing our presence in very dynamic markets. We are best positioned candidate to consolidate the European tower landscape. We're also taking the first steps to become the European leader in the distributed antenna systems sector.
From operations perspective, our efficiency plan is on track, while we have also recovered TV revenues we lost in the past. And finally, we are glad to announce that Cellnex has been included in the IBEX 35 Index.
Moving now to Slide 5. In terms of activities, we have managed to increase the number of PoPs by 2% compared to December 2015. We are also paving the way to boost our presence in the DAS business by acquiring CommsCon. CommsCon provides today DAS services in 83 locations in Italy and is analyzing many additional projects in environments where an important demand for mobile data is seen. We continue to assess the possibility to invest in fiber backhauling to the tower for our customers, and we are making good progress on this front. We're closely monitoring and proactively analyzing potential new opportunities that might arise from the consolidation of the fourth mobile operator role across Europe.
Finally, we continue to pursue rationalization projects with mobile operators, and we are working hard to reach an agreement in the short term.
Regarding broadcasting, we can confirm that the retendering process of the 6 new TV channels have successfully been completed with all Chinese broadcasting and generating earnings from April, thus, providing a stable revenue release, going forward.
Regarding the network services and others, we continue to see a solid performance, faster connectivity and emergency communications businesses. It is important to highlight that we -- that when we enter any country, we pursue new services levering on our Telecom Site Rental activity.
Finally, we keep analyzing any single opportunity at hand to continue creating value for our shareholders. And one such opportunity is our efficiency program, on which we are making good progress according to the timing I really [ph] share with you.
Turning to Slide 6. You can see here the evolution of PoPs and our resulting consolidated tenancy ratio, with increases being explained by consistent organic growth rates. We have managed to add more than 400 PoPs in the period reaching a tenancy ratio of 1.56, a 4% increase when compared to June 2015 and a 2% increase when compared to December 2015.
On the next chart, you can find a comprehensive explanation of the performance of revenues in the Telecom Site Rental business. You can see how the shifting asset base contributes EUR 4 million to our consolidated figures, while the change of perimeter adds EUR 54 million in this period.
When we've not adjusted EBITDA, you can see how the negative impact of the DTT single cut that took place in 2015, which was a one-off positive effect, is more than offset by the switch on our new TV channels, the change of perimeter and the contribution of organic growth, which represent EUR 4 million in the period.
Let me now explain in detail on Slide 7, our recurring levered free cash flow generation in the period. I would like to start by highlighting that the cash conversion ratio of EBITDA into current level free cash flow in the period has been 94%, with current cash flow increasing by 24%.
Looking now to revenues. Telecom Site Rental increases mainly due to our strong organic growth and acquisitions. The broadcasting business reflects now the new TV channels from April when compared to the previous quarter. And network services and other continue showing a solid performance, mainly due to a high activity in the connectivity business.
Moving to OpEx. We have a very well-contained cost base with a flat performance on a like-for-like basis. The increase is mainly due to cost directly associated with our recent transactions. Our adjusted EBITDA reached EUR 134 million, in line with our guidance for the full year, and showing a strong 17% increase when compared to last year.
Maintenance CapEx is well below our 3% guidance for the year, due to a time effect and is expected to catch up within this year to reach a more normalized level.
Our working capital change is neutral for the period, thanks to our strict management, and in line with our full year guidance.
Interest paid reflect our current capital structure with the first coupon associated with our bond paid this week, therefore, to be considered for the next quarter. And tax paid reflect the implementation of tax management measure as well as the tax payment scheduled in the year.
Non-M&A expansion CapEx include the first step of our efficiency program with EUR 12 million associated with cash advances in the context or the renegotiation of our leases.
Moving now to our balance sheet on Slide 8. Cellnex leverage has decreased to 3.3x net debt annualized EBITDA, well below our long-term objective of 4x. Our total net debt is EUR 872 million, with our bond accounting for most of the debt. We're now setting the change in net debt and is needs to be taken into account. That in general, we paid the second tranche of Volta Extended phase 2. And in June, we paid acquisition of CommsCon. You will find all these details in the Excel sheet that is in our website. 
We have also paid our final dividend in July, bringing the total distribution to around EUR 20 million, approximately 20% of the recurring levered free cash flow generated in the second half of 2015, in accordance with our dividend policy.
Coming back to the remaining lines of our income statement, depreciation and amortization credits increased mainly as a result of our recent acquisitions. And interest expense increased in line with our capital structure.
Moving to Slide 9. You can see on the left-hand side our capital structure, with near liquidity lines having been signed at a very competitive cost of around 1%, alone for new upcoming growth opportunities.
On the right-hand side, you can see also our debt maturities profile compared to our cash flow generation in a cumulative basis. We can, therefore, in summary, say that we face no refinancing risk due to the long-term [indiscernible] of our debt and our cash flow generation capacity. We have improved our liquidity position. And we have a solid credit rating with our Standard & Poor's outlook having been improved recently. On that, our recent acquisition have been financed at a very low marginal cost.
So now regarding the M&A update. Given our high M&A activity, during the last weeks, we believe it is worth offering a brief recap of our last year's and also provide some additional background on how these transactions fit into our equity story. 
If we now move to Slide 11. You can see a summary of our recent activity. 251 towers in Holland. An agreement with Bouygues to buy up to 500 towers in France and acquisition of Commscon in Italy. These deals represent the first step into very dynamic market. They allow us to diversify into countries with a strong credit rating. Hopefully, next, the right platform from which continue to assess and [indiscernible] consolidation opportunities, and therefore, confirm the delivery on our equity story.
On Slide 12, you can see a picture of a new Cellnex perimeter as a result of the recent transactions. More markets, more diversified client base, more focused portfolio on Telecom Site Rental revenues. All-in-all, we can clearly state that after these appreciations, our business risk profile has improved.
Moving to Slide 13. You can see here a table that shows how to think about capital generation from our recent acquisition. The cash conversion ratio from EBITDA into recurrent levered free cash flow is 85%. So I think this figure is very, very high. The new deals are expected to generate EUR 12 million on a full year basis in terms of recurring levered free cash flow. This represents around 10% of the recurring cash flow generated in the first semester 2016, and all this has been achieved always by applying our strict investment criteria.
So now if we assess the different opportunities one after the other, first of all, on Slide 14, you can see a more detailed assessment of our DAS deal that we closed the first day of July. The main idea I would like to highlight is that we are entering a new market with a strong anchor tenant, providing with revenues visibility, and we follow on opportunities that should come in the next quarter. 
Also, there are other characteristics of this deal, such as the high proportion of revenues guaranteed with new clients, in this case, KPN, until 2017, 2018. The tariff scheme, which is in Brexit to CPI having a flow at 0%.
And finally, I would like to say that 20% of the sites that we've acquired overlaps with existing networks of our operators.
On the Slide 16 -- sorry, 15. Here, we present the French opportunity, and this project is an industrial project that sets the foundation for a long-term partnership with a key European player, like Bouygues. One example of this future cooperation is our preemptive right to build up to 250 sites for our anchor tenant. It is important to highlight that this acquisition, unlike the Dutch one, consist on the acquisition of assets of towers. Also, there are other characteristics that make this opportunity unique, such as a very long-term contract of 20 years and also a 2% annual fix fee escalator.
Moving now to Italy on Slide 16. The acquisition of CommsCon represents the opportunity for Cellnex to become the DAS benchmark in Europe. We believe the DAS market has a huge potential and will position Cellnex in the future DAS sector as it is developed. This acquisition provides us with a first-mover advantage and the knowhow required to achieve this leadership. We do really think that CommsCon is a unique platform to capture what we think will be a very significant market in the next years.
At the end of the day, CommsCon will help us to cover -- or to improve the coverage that we can provide from our infrastructures.
Finally, on Slide 17, we present what we call the domino affect, the strategy that we have been implementing for our European expansion. Our intention is to continue acquiring small portfolios in new countries so that we can increase our understanding of the market, build a strong relationship with the aim to continue consolidated [indiscernible] market by pursuing new opportunities. This is what we have successfully done in the past, and is a path that we would follow in order to become the European consolidator.
In Slide 19, just some closing remarks. We are presenting today a solid set of results. We are happy to deliver our equity story, not only from a revenue perspective but also from M&A activity. We continued to be place very well position to consolidate the European tower landscape. We are taking the first step to become the European leader in the new technologies at a step-by-step far more important like the DAS. Current operations are strong, and our efficiency plan is on track. And finally, Cellnex has been included in the IBEX 35. It has already improved the visibility, the liquidity and attractiveness of our store, as you can see in Page 20.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Three questions from my side. First one on M&A. You could comment a bit on what your intentions are in France and Holland after your first acquisitions? What is your view, the critical portfolio size, you would like to achieve? And if you could give a bit
componenttext: Three questions from my side. First one on M&A. You could comment a bit on what your intentions are in France and Holland after your first acquisitions? What is your view, the critical portfolio size, you would like to achieve? And if you could give a bit of guidance on time frame you think you will need to achieve the optimal portfolio size? And then maybe something on an update on the Hutchison portfolio in Italy? That's first question. Second, an OpEx, I understand you could roughly save EUR 50 million from these negotiations over the next 3 to 4 years. Now my question is, how much of that amount do you expect to achieve this year? Then last question on the Russian evasion [ph] process, and 2,000 towers decommissioning you guided to during full year results. Could you give some update on that?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. Thank you very much. Regarding your first question, which was France, Holland and the next steps and time frame. In fact, I think in page -- in the annex in Page 22, you can find the market description of the Netherlands and France. And y
componenttext:
Okay, thank you. Thank you very much. Regarding your first question, which was France, Holland and the next steps and time frame. In fact, I think in page -- in the annex in Page 22, you can find the market description of the Netherlands and France. And you can see how, for instance, in the Netherlands, there are different tower costs. And there's a footnote that is displaying which tower cost there are there. So we are talking at least 1,200 towers from Tower Company. And on top of that, there are other MNOs that have already, let's say, 13,000 towers. We will think that the market is moving, and there will be some angle to consolidate in the next quarter.
Again, the question is always execution versus value criterion. We have to give you an answer regarding when it is very important to understand the criteria's requirement. So it's not easy to tell you. The thing is, we are working on that. We are monitoring this market pretty closely. Also, the French market, French market, again, in Page 22, you can see that there are different MNOs with, let's say, around 50,000 towers. And some TowerCos with 10,000 towers. You all know and it is market -- it is public information that some of these TowerCos potentially may be on sale in the next quarter in competitive process from a public perspective, we can say that, at least. There will be one opportunity in France, hopefully. Your second question was regarding the OpEx. In fact, you were asking about the capital bonds program that we have. First of all, let me tell you that the capital bonds program is working as expected. And we're pretty sure we can get this EUR 15 million by 2019, I think, it was the target. This year, I think that if we go on investing as we are investing around EUR 3 million, EUR 2 million, let's say, EUR 2 million or EUR 3 million depending the timing effect can be obtained. Please be aware that this is, if you invest 1 year, for instance, EUR 20 million in cash advance, it's not the same investing this EUR 20 million at first day of the year or the last date of the year. So it depends. At this time frame have an impact on 2015 numbers. However, all these transactions always follow our very strict criteria. So the payback will there, if not this year, next year. Finally, regarding the consolidation of the market, the 2,000 towers [indiscernible] this month, again, same message as previous quarters. I think we are working a lot and I'm pretty sure that we will present to you an interesting deal. The thing is that each day longer than expected, to be honest. However, it is taking longer because also I don't think that Cellnex is opening this market and providing very good ideas and new angles that have to be explored. Pretty sure that we will come out one day to the market with something positive. Or at least you will see quarter-by-quarter that the number of towers change, and therefore, the PoPs grow, right?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had 3 questions, please. Starting in Italy, as we consider the implications of Italian MNO consolidation, it would be good to progress the debate from the organic growth opportunities of new entrants to now better understanding, in your view, what your
componenttext: I had 3 questions, please. Starting in Italy, as we consider the implications of Italian MNO consolidation, it would be good to progress the debate from the organic growth opportunities of new entrants to now better understanding, in your view, what your P&L is, as an industrial partner as Iliad relative to your competition in Italy? And staying in Italy, I really have an extension of the previous question. As we look at the accelerated investments announced earlier this week by Inwit, it's clear that TI is probably now not a seller of that state, so given M&A is off the table and also given Inwit is investing to drive growth, do you have any reason to change your capital allocation in Italy? And lastly, on spectrum, at the end of May, we saw the GSMA again pushed for a more aggressive time line for the reconsideration of the sub-700 megahertz band for alternative uses. It'd be interesting to hear your perspective on this development? And how this shift is debated at all for the outlook, for DTT in the sub-700 megahertz band, if at all?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you Giles for your questions. Let me split your questions into parts, 1 and 2 will be answered by myself, and the third one I will invite Alex Mestre, who is the International Director to answer to your question in the GSM 700 megahertz. Giles, I th
componenttext: Thank you Giles for your questions. Let me split your questions into parts, 1 and 2 will be answered by myself, and the third one I will invite Alex Mestre, who is the International Director to answer to your question in the GSM 700 megahertz. Giles, I think, your first and second question, I think both come at the same time. We are not going to change our plan because of our peer is changing their CapEx plan. I mean, we will have to go on working, following our internal targets with a criteria we have in order to create value for our shareholders. We think that the Italian market, from my perspective, presents a lot of opportunities, one of them being the fourth operator. Obviously, Cellnex is keeping twice on this process, and I think we have the open to asses with different candidates in this opportunity. I think that Cellnex is very well positioned. Cellnex has, let's say, a tenancy ratio in Italy which is 1.2x. So it gives us headroom to grow, give us headroom to put more tenants into our towers as a place now that Italy presents a very demanding electromagnetic revolution. So in this case, having a low tenancy ratio is helpful to grow, is helpful to offer new PoPs. And second, also, I don't think that we are very well positioned to play a key role in this fourth operator and process because we are neutral operator. We are independent tower company, so we do not have any MNO on our shareholding base, and therefore, it will give us headroom, will give us flexibility to treat all our customers in the same way with the same criteria. So I do think that Cellnex is doing -- working -- doing good progress, but always on a very confidential basis and on a very prudent basis, step-by-step. I don't know if Alex Mestre, you can help me to answer the third question.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, José Manuel. On relation to the spectrum, I think it's true that the 700 megahertz is something that the World Radio Conference is also [indiscernible] that at certain point in time, it is required to do a reallocation of the usage of the band
componenttext: Yes, sure, José Manuel. On relation to the spectrum, I think it's true that the 700 megahertz is something that the World Radio Conference is also [indiscernible] that at certain point in time, it is required to do a reallocation of the usage of the band. Remember, like remember, we have the 800 megahertz has already been cleared and now is being used for 4G. Also, I would like to emphasize the concept of the lower the frequencies, the longer the range. So I believe that when an MNO is looking for identification, using -- traveling more kind of a small cells, more microcells, more DAS that José Manuel has been explaining in one of the trends as of now. Those frequencies are less interesting because the coverage is much wider than higher frequency. So in relation, identification in the lower frequencies are not as useful as the higher frequencies. In relation to the 700 megahertz, it is clear that the number of stages in Europe have to prepare their clients. This is something that will occur during -- in 2017. Some of the countries have an accelerated plan in relation to that, but when research that in countries like Spain, and as a result also of the latest, let's say, prepositions which is having, in Europe, we understood that it is not going to happen before 2022. And it is the period that has been the frequency rate possible, also within 2020, 2022. And, importantly, during that process and that time, until then, the broadcasting terminologies that will evolve, is able to do an evolution. It will be maybe [indiscernible] visibility to higher compression mechanisms that will keep the overall offer of channels, even migrating them to high definition, very equal as we have today. So in that sense, we expect that in those countries, specifically in Spain, where we have the broadcasting presence as of today, we will remain with a similar offer in terms of digital [indiscernible] than rest of the channels.

From that point onwards, what is expected is that the final candidate [indiscernible] will be the one finally getting into the agreement -- with the new merged entity. It is true having other candidates. We've been having discussions logically with all of them. And our value proposition has been, we understand, properly understood, especially in relation to what José Manuel was saying that the low tenancy ratio, in that case, where we are now, it is an advantage because it allows us, let's say, to fit very quickly and in a very big amount of number of sites and new mobile network operator.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Few questions. I think, let me go in order. It should be relatively straightforward. The very first line is on France. You mentioned that there should be a follow-up deal for the 270 towers. Do you also think that we have similar terms in terms of length
componenttext: Few questions. I think, let me go in order. It should be relatively straightforward. The very first line is on France. You mentioned that there should be a follow-up deal for the 270 towers. Do you also think that we have similar terms in terms of length and EBITDA contribution. The second one is on credit. You show in the appendix, a chart, where it looks like the yield on your bond gradually falling for a number of regions. And so my question is, considering you still finance yourself with credit facility, there would be no time now to turn that short- to medium-term credit facility into long-term bond? The third is on CommsCon. Now it's a slightly different -- this is broader than what we've seen in previous deals. The other deals you've got a lot of clarity in terms of the length, and therefore, it's easier to model from our standpoint. Here today, you showed a contribution around EUR 1.5 million on EBITDA. So the question is how secure is EBITDA? What sort of length in the contract we got behind? And what are the ultimate payers for that particular -- underpin [ph] that EBITDA and then also third party? And the very last one, and that one, it's a small [indiscernible] than everything else. We talk a lot about this [indiscernible] a lot of contract and the fact that WIND cannot get half of that contract. But can we, with your approval, basically on a tower-to-tower basis potentially pass the contract to another operator? I mean, we're not talking about newcomers. Of course, nothing at WIND and Hutchison had complete their business plan in terms of the towers they want to get out. But in case they basically they try that, for them, it will be good to get out of some of the towers in which they sold to you, and of course, they locked for 15 years. But if they pay or if they negotiate with you, would you be willing to basically for them to sell the contract onto a third party?

componenttextpreview: Sorry, I understood that the question was another. You're right, Ottavio, sorry, sorry. So yes, you're right. This deal, the Bouygues deal, 500 towers, is a split in 2 parts now, 230 and 270 towers. And the economical terms comparing the EBITDA contributi
componenttext: Sorry, I understood that the question was another. You're right, Ottavio, sorry, sorry. So yes, you're right. This deal, the Bouygues deal, 500 towers, is a split in 2 parts now, 230 and 270 towers. And the economical terms comparing the EBITDA contribution and the enterprise value are similar. So yes, it is [indiscernible] I thought you were asking for [indiscernible]. But the answer is yes, this 500 towers are coherent in terms of the relationship between the EBITDA contribution and then the [indiscernible] value required by the [indiscernible]. So the second question talks about Page 23. Of course, you know, Ottavio, that personally, I monitor the market on a daily basis and [indiscernible] every step you can see how the green line is tightening [ph] and is getting more nearer now to our benchmark. And just, of course, I think that Cellnex has to keep an eye on it, and as soon as the market might be open or might be one in an attractive condition for us because of the market is open. So now it is a question of [indiscernible], a question of when we will be, for sure, really to fund the company not because we need it because we [indiscernible] need it. I mean, we are not in a rush. But just on opportunistic basis to capture maybe a bond, a long-term bond that allow us to look at low interest rate for a very long term, and therefore, be more value accretive when we acquire a company. So yes, the answer is yes, we are monitoring the market. Also, your third question was regarding CommsCon. So in order to answer that question may be we can go to Page 25. So in Page 25, we will have to try to represent a little bit business model of CommsCon now. And there are 3 boxes: venue owners; Cellnex, where we do with CommsCon now; and our customers. If you follow this graph, you will see that Cellnex pays a rental fee to the venue owner, to make it very simple. And Cellnex deploys CapEx and incurs the OpEx of managing the system. And as a consequence of this, we receive money, a fee by the MNO. So obviously, the EUR 1.5 million EBITDA, how sustainable it is? We'll think it is sustainable. We'll think it is going to grow in the future. And look at something here. The fees that they may not pay to us has 2 parts. The first part is stagnant -- initially stagnant or after the consideration for the infrastructure that will build up for the system. And second, we'll receive different installments for a long period of time, so enough from consolidation and then long-term payments. Therefore, we'll think that this EUR 1.5 million is sustainable and as the market develops -- because in Europe, the opportunity is massive. All of us would have gone to put a very simple example. In London, now when you go London Lounge and maybe you have progress in order to send a WhatsApp in order to go on with a conversation. And so as this situation in London, there are many other situation in Europe. And we think that with CommsCon, we are very well placed in order to improve this coverage and to fill in these gaps. And finally, the fourth question, maybe Alex you can help me. Already, Ottavio, you can repeat it, because -- but I don't know, I mean, Alex as you wish.

And then there will be another bunch of sites that will be probably dispose or offered to Iliad because neither we, neither Hutch will be occupying them. So when it is explained into the press that the new fourth MNO will have access to certain sites, our understanding, [indiscernible] understanding or industrial understanding is that either they will be offered by the merge entity of those sites that will no longer be of the interest by the entity or will be offered at some hosting on the survival sites that the entity will , let's say, next [indiscernible] among them. On the top of the sites that other MNO [indiscernible] might be offering to the new entity. So when this is explained in the press release, it is most likely the kind of offer that the new entity will be viewing to the fourth [indiscernible].

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for taking my questions. I've got just, what, let's say, 3 one -- 3 short ones. Well, the first one is on the mobile backhaul. You said in the past that you have sort of demands from a number of clients regarding that opportunity. I know for a f
componenttext: Thank you for taking my questions. I've got just, what, let's say, 3 one -- 3 short ones. Well, the first one is on the mobile backhaul. You said in the past that you have sort of demands from a number of clients regarding that opportunity. I know for a fact that one of the clients is very, very keen on such an idea. But maybe can you give us maybe good color about the sort of breadth of the demand that you're seeing, both in Italy and Spain. And maybe add a little bit of sort of economics of the -- all this opportunity. My second question is more of a sort of long-term structural one. Looking at your new markets, both Netherlands and France, do you see sort of a change in shift regarding willingness of MNOs to dispose of the towers? I mean, we know that we've sold in France, we know that [indiscernible] sold in France. We know that KPN sold in that business a while back. But there have been more or less kind of keeping the towers on the books. Do you see if there are any shifts there we should be aware of? And my third question [indiscernible] one, regarding sort of the Telecom Italia's development of new towers with Inwit, will there be any competitive pressure on you immediately? I presume it's no, but just want to make sure that's the case.

componenttext: Sure, not a problem. I mean, you know that Telecom Italia wants to -- is basically asking it to deploy and construct a whole bunch of towers in Italy. I just want to know if there'll be any competitive pressure on you because of that. I mean, I presume that's not the case, but just want to make sure.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So okay, understood. No -- yes, to answer this question, no, no, we have no pressure -- more pressure because of this announcement. And we said before, we're going with our own plan. We have seen that our strategy is the right one. We are independent comp
componenttext: So okay, understood. No -- yes, to answer this question, no, no, we have no pressure -- more pressure because of this announcement. And we said before, we're going with our own plan. We have seen that our strategy is the right one. We are independent company. So we have to follow working with our different clients on a neutral basis. So no, we keep on working, okay? Regarding your second question, the disposal of towers and if there is any change now in the attitude. This is -- Cellnex is a long-term investor and is a long-term player. So we don't think that in the short term, in one quarter to the other quarter, things are going to be from black to white or from white to black, no. We -- I think that we're working a lot with many European MNOs. We are trying to explain our business model to bring to the table the benefits of it. And obviously, as a result of this work, step-by-step very progressively, things will change, and for instance, had a change in France for us with this opportunity, which we think is very important and significant. But no, you will never change -- big changes from one thing to the other. However, this is our gradual working, which we are very well positioned. And finally, regarding the first question, I would like maybe Alex, you can help us.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to complete the last one, I think there is an important issue maybe to emphasize. Which I am [indiscernible] is that, José Manuel, that have not been disposing towers, there is still, I believe, that tower is a critical technical asset. So probably
componenttext: Just to complete the last one, I think there is an important issue maybe to emphasize. Which I am [indiscernible] is that, José Manuel, that have not been disposing towers, there is still, I believe, that tower is a critical technical asset. So probably the first department that has to be convinced in order to go in this direction that financially could make sense  is the technical department. Then we speak the technical language. And as industrial player, for us, it's not difficult, let's say, to tune the frequencies, because we talk about frequencies -- keeping the frequencies with our counterparties in the technical departments of [indiscernible] it can establish a comfort, let's say, discussion that could, let's say, lower those entry barriers that maybe is another type of potential where you're more financially responsible, another kind of interested party to either towers could be a little bit more difficult. So we believe that as industry player, we have essential technical advantage there on having this technical-to-technical discussion. On your first question, which was these mobile backhaul. Yes, this is true. So densification, more technologies in a single tower means more bandwidth. And more frequencies per tower means more bandwidth to be delivered to each tower. Then normally, this is done by Microwaves. So radio links, there is no fiber. However, the demand of these more bandwidth requires, in many cases, to substitute the radio links with fiber. And this is a process where all of the MNOs are as of today investing or continuing to invest in the coming years. Specifically, we were allowed to offer 4G, [indiscernible] that requirement are much more demanding. Our interest there is because we believe that this backhaul can be neutralized. So there is no strategic advantage, let's say, on that. And the fact of having a CapEx that could be neutralized it is very much what is our business about. And our intention is to stay at the dark fiber level. So it means we are not intending to enter into optical electronics, into connectivity, which sometimes changes a little the profile of the operation and maintenance of this type of agreement. So we intend to stay on the dark fiber, let's say, layer of value proposition to the MNOs. And in relation to the economics, this may be very different on depending where the tower is, as you can imagine, and how far is the main backhaul is far from the tower, because then you need to do some sort of construction to build from the backbone to the tower some CapEx there, could be 30 meters, could be 3 kilometers. So that, as you can imagine, is going to depend very, very much. And the idea is to understand the needs of the MNOs. In Italy, we have around 15% of our towers with fiber, so there is [indiscernible] very, very clear. And now with the new MNO potential, this neutralization effect that we were mentioning is much more obvious. So we believe that the opportunities are clearly there. There is a small budget that we're doing in Italy on that in the range of, let's say, dozens of towers to put fiber on our side. This is helping us to understand also the retail economy [indiscernible] the complexity of doing that. Based on that, we will, let's say, take a more stern step towards putting fiber to our towers. We see the fiber to the towers like the roots of a tree. When you have these roots, it's more difficult to move the tower. So also in terms of long-term sustainability of the contracts, we believe that it's also bringing value on the top of that.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: My first question is on your recent acquisitions in the Netherlands, France and Italy. Can you give an indication on when they will become accretive from an earnings per share point of view? And the second question is on possible future M&A. Now if in one of the markets where you are present, if you have the opportunity to acquire, control other towers operator, which is primarily broadcasting but also with telco towers, would that be an appealing opportunity for you? And my third question is maybe going back to the DAS, if you can maybe give us an idea on the profitability in terms of EBITDA margin and top line revenue growth rate, please.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Luigi, thank you very much for your questions. Regarding your first question, which was the accretive impact of these acquisitions on recurring levered free cash flow. And the answer, I think we [indiscernible] we can go to base testing [indiscernib
componenttext: Okay. Luigi, thank you very much for your questions. Regarding your first question, which was the accretive impact of these acquisitions on recurring levered free cash flow. And the answer, I think we [indiscernible] we can go to base testing [indiscernible] you can see here, the EBITDA that on a ground rate basis we expect from this period for 2017. So -- and after that, we deduct the maintenance CapEx, the taxes, the working capital, the interest expenses. And therefore, after this EBITDA is converted into recurring levered free cash flow, so the thing is that out of these EUR 14.5 million of EBITDA that we are acquiring, we convert into cash flow for our shareholders EUR 12 million. So we do think that it is a very high conversion ratio. And we can't do that, because we have a very strict policy in terms of maintenance CapEx and working capital. And we do -- we try -- we structure all the transactions in a way that from a DAS perspective, we can be competitive. And also as we were speaking before, from an interest expense perspective, we are opportunistic and we take advantage to fund these transactions in a very competitive way. So the answer is yes, these transactions are accretive from day 1, so we don't have to wait 2 or 3 years to see the cash flow per share to be increased. 2017 and even 2016, the recurring levered free cash flow per share will be increased because of these transactions. Your second question will be -- if I recall, it was regarding M&A, when M&A is considering telco broadcasting opportunities altogether. As you can read in our IOM and also in the [indiscernible], you will see that we clearly state that our objective is to step by step increase our exposure to Telecom Site Rental. It is true that also if in order to do so we have to acquire broadcasting, we might assess the opportunity. But that will not be an end but a mean to get what we want on which we are focused, which is the Telecom Site Rental business. So this is the reality, focus on Telecom Site Rental. And your last question, which I think is EBITDA growth of DAS, I think maybe Alex, you can help us a little bit here.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. [indiscernible] the question was often also related on the economics of those projects. So as José Manuel was saying, Page 25 we try to explain a little bit how DAS work. There is one key element that makes those project, let's say, different projec
componenttext: Yes. [indiscernible] the question was often also related on the economics of those projects. So as José Manuel was saying, Page 25 we try to explain a little bit how DAS work. There is one key element that makes those project, let's say, different project-by-project can be categorized in different type of projects. And then, of course, economics may change, especially in relation to the investment. So in many cases, if the venue owner who is limited of some investment, because it brings more [indiscernible] of the venue, because it is -- the owner of the big building that wants to [indiscernible] coverage, so as you can imagine, those projects where there is some CapEx already being deployed by the venue owner are different than the ones that we need to go through the MNOs, convincing them that it is worth to use some CapEx there and then get the critical mass to roll out the project with [indiscernible] and then other [indiscernible] and also having some sort of revenue share if there is one initial [indiscernible]. It is a mix of different models that, to be very honest, we are now understanding -- starting to understand  the complexity. And that's the reason that we acquired the company, which is very much specialized on that niche market. And the key element here is now to try to industrialize a little bit all those concepts and going beyond Italy or more than Italy where these company has been more or less having their commercial activity, going beyond on a difficult culture [indiscernible] try to adapt the model and being able to, let's say, achieve what we are [indiscernible] in the presentation to be a DAS leader operator in Europe. And this is our ambition, and we believe that with all this knowledge that we are acquiring [indiscernible] that we can move forward this process. As of today, some of those DAS elements the only way of being deployed are among in and of themselves. And sometimes, the [indiscernible], let's say, some time to market constraints. So we believe that being the independent player, we can catalyze and enable those projects in a faster way that until now we have somehow, let's say, delayed in time.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll try to. I think it is important to maybe do a little bit [indiscernible] on what is the active equipment that we deploy on the DAS. We do not deploy the base station, so the [indiscernible] architecture, and if you go to Page 25, it is clear on
componenttext: Yes, I'll try to. I think it is important to maybe do a little bit [indiscernible] on what is the active equipment that we deploy on the DAS. We do not deploy the base station, so the [indiscernible] architecture, and if you go to Page 25, it is clear on the central picture. And still you see that on the left side of the central picture, there are a few equipments, those are the DTS. So the equipment -- typical equipment that goes into the tower is this one, the one which is on the left, which is the #1, #2 and #3. This -- CapEx in this period from the MNO. So we are not entering, let's say, on to the active equipment at the complexity of a base station. What we do is this DTH [indiscernible] and the nodes and the fiber, we get the signal and the acronym tries to explain what it is. It is a distributed antenna. So we get the signal from DTS and we spread it through a wide coverage area. Instead of having 1 antenna each, for every node we put 10 to 15 antennas. That's the reason that as of today we have something like 900, almost 1,000 nodes, and every node is having 10 to 12 antennas. That's the reason we have up to 12,000 antennas in those systems overall as of today coming from the CommsCon acquisition. So the complexity of sharing the antenna is much less than the complexity of sharing the active agreement. Which then becomes a rank sharing sort of asking. So here, we are not talking about sharing the radio station, we just sharing a distributed antenna which being difficult to deploy in a venue like a stadium, for the [indiscernible] is probably the best way to do it or the only way is to do by sharing. That's the reason that most of the DAS systems as of today are starting from a shared system among different [indiscernible]. But they need to agree amongst themselves to do that. And maybe one has more intelligent in one area, the other in the other, so acting as an enabler of that process makes the situation easier, and where we believe we can get, let's say, an expansion of that business model to other areas. That is not -- it's different electronics, I don't know if I was clear myself. And what maybe your second question that I am not answering or did I answer everything?

And we do think that eventually that -- no, that finally we'll get it, and we're doing good progress, even though slowly than expected. Why slowly? Because, I mean, the [indiscernible] is open in the market is -- and this requires times, requires to assess different angles, to be patient. And I think as a long-term player, we are very well positioned to capture this market opportunity.

componenttext: Okay, yes. As we have done in Italy and as we have done in the Netherlands and as we have done in France, we do think that it makes sense as a first step in these countries with clients, with new clients for us in our towers, it makes sense to acquire, first of all, a small -- some towers in order to learn, in order to understand opportunities, and then step-by-step, to follow the domino effect that we present in Page 17 of the presentation. So the answer is yes, we think it's prudent, we think it makes sense. And if possible, this is our preferred strategy.

componenttext: Yes, in relation to the fourth. So seems that the #4 is the magic number now. And we'd like to protect ourselves [indiscernible]. And we always consider it in our business scale, there could be a consolidation, any further consolidation from 4 to 3. However, it seems that this is not going to be the case. And Jonathan, you're absolutely right that this brings consolidation opportunity that in many cases has not been authorized. And it is very much welcome from the perspective of the other TowerCo operator. Having said that, let's see how that evolves, okay? Let's see that finally it gets approval in Italy. Also, what we foresee in those additional countries where we are is that there is, yes, a challenger that needs to rapidly deploy coverage and most likely trust to do on their own, because the grant-sharing agreement and growing an [indiscernible] revenue is easy. So for us, yes, it brings in additional opportunity that we are doing, let's say, [indiscernible] in order to capture.
