headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, and I'm the Head of Investor Relations for Cellnex. I'm joined today by José Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director, who will lead today's presentation. And I would like to thank you for joining us today for C
componenttext: Good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, and I'm the Head of Investor Relations for Cellnex. I'm joined today by José Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director, who will lead today's presentation. And I would like to thank you for joining us today for Cellnex's Q3 2016 Results Conference Call. We have, earlier today, posted our presentation, which we will refer to throughout our prepared remarks, under the Investor Relations section on our website. And then, we'll open the lines for a Q&A session. So now I'll hand over to Jose Manuel. Please, Jose Manuel?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you so much for your time today. And as a reminder, please note that additional financial information can be obtained on the Investor Relations section of our website, where a detailed Excel file is available. Now please allow me to
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you so much for your time today. And as a reminder, please note that additional financial information can be obtained on the Investor Relations section of our website, where a detailed Excel file is available. Now please allow me to start by highlighting the main milestones of the period. 
If you go to Slide 4, you can see that, today, we are presenting again a solid set of results that show a strong growth in terms of adjusted EBITDA and recurring level free cash flow per share when compared to the same period last year. We are also showing solid organic growth in our Telecom Site Rental business that confirms the market expectations for the period. We are delivering on our equity story by executing new accretive acquisitions, consistent with our strategy for international expansion. We successfully show a second bond, making the most of an attractive market environment, with the objective to stand maturities at very competitive terms. 
We are taking the further step to become the European leader in the distributed antenna system sector, whilst positioning Cellnex to capture potential opportunities associated with the future rollout of 5G. And finally, enough execution firepower is still available to continue growing, while maintaining our current credit rating for being eligible in the ECB program. 
Moving now to Slide 5. In terms of activity, we have managed to increase the number of PoPs by 3% when compared to December 2015, and even the number of DAS notes in Italy in just a very short period of time: 3 months. We are proactively analyzing new opportunities that might arise from the consolidation of the fourth mobile operator role across Europe. We continue to pursue tower rationalization opportunities with our clients, and our first project is now ongoing. We are also accelerating our Build to Suit program, while additionally assessing the attractiveness to invest in fiber backhauling to the tower for our customers. 
In the broadcasting business, the return in [ph] process of 6 new TV channels was successfully completed with all private channels, generating revenues from the beginning of fiber [ph]. In the network services and other business, we continue to see a solid performance. I have signed 2 new contracts in the context of Smart Cities broadband connectivity in our mobility environment. 
Finally, we analyze any single opportunity we find to continue creating value for our shareholders. And such opportunities can be found by efficiently operating our business, improving our capital structure or proactively managing our working capital and taxes, which contribute to our strong recurrent levered free cash flow generation in the period. 
Turning to Slide #6. You can see here the evolution of PoPs and our resulting consolidated tenancy ratio, with increases being explained by consistent organic growth rates and recent change of perimeter. We have managed to organically add almost 700 PoPs in the period, reaching a tenancy ratio of 1.58x. 
On the next chart, you can find a comprehensive explanation of the revenue's evolution in the Telecom Site Rental business. You can see here how the existing asset base contributes with EUR 6 million of revenues to our consolidated figure, while the change of perimeter, mainly Galata and Protelindo, add EUR 58 million in that period. 
Moving now to consolidated adjusted EBITDA. You can see how the negative impact of the DTT simulcast that took place in 2015, which was a one-off positive effect not seen in the year, is more than offset by the switch on of the new TV channels, the contribution of our organic growth and the change of perimeter. 
Let may now explain in detail on Slide 7 our recurrent levered free cash flow generation for the period. I would like to start by highlighting that the cash conversion ratio of EBITDA into recurrent levered free cash flow in the period has been a strong 88%, with the total figure increasing by 26% when compared to 2015. 
Looking at the revenues, the contribution from all the different businesses lines increased with a very well contained cost base, leading to adjusted EBITDA growth of 18% when compared to last year. Maintenance CapEx is below our guidance, but is expected to increase during the last quarter to reach more normalized levels. Our working capital change is positive for the period, but expected to be neutral at the year-end, in line with our guidance. 
Interests paid reflect our capital structure as of September, with a coupon associated with our first bond being paid in Q3. Taxes paid reflect implementation of tax management measures, as well as the schedule of tax payment due in the year. 
So as you can see, in Page 7, our revenues grow by 15%, our adjusted EBITDA grows 18% and recurring levered free cash flow grows even further at 26%. This is one of the key characteristics of Cellnex.  We can grow beyond our revenue growth. 
Moving now to our balance sheet on Slide 8. Cellnex's leverage for the period has reached 3.7x net debt annualized EBITDA and is expected to reach 4.5x at year-end, including the closing of our recently announced acquisition, Shere. Our total borrowings, which are around EUR 1.3 billion with our 2 bonds accounting for all of our debt. When assessing the change in net debt, it needs to be taken into account M&A, interest payments and dividend distribution in the period. Please note that our next dividend payment will be submitted for approval at our Board of Directors meeting that will take place later in December. 
Moving to Slide 9. We have so far explained our debt position as of end of September. But given our recent developments, it is worth providing a more updated picture on our capital structure as of today. You can see on the left-hand side our current capital structure with new debt instruments, having been signed at a very competitive cost of around 1%, allowing for additional debt associated with potential upcoming growth opportunities. 
Before, we have today a net debt position of EUR 1.47 billion, with additional debt available of around EUR 600 million. On the right-hand side, you can see our debt maturities profile and how it compares with our cash flow generation in cumulative terms, which shows how our cash flow generation covers future financing needs. 
In summary, we have a solid and long-term structure in place with no restrictions. We are, today, a current issuer with a strong market support, and we are committed with our solid credit rating in order to maintain the eligibility for the purchase program of the European Central Bank. 
Moving to Slide 10. The assumptions we have shared in previous periods behind our financial outlook for the full year 2016 are still valid. We provide in 2015 our recurrent levered free cash flow per share increase of 28%, and we're expecting in 2016 an increase of well above 20%. We are proud to show a consistent and significant increase of our key value creation metric over the years. Given our recent M&A activity, we believe it is worth again offering a quick update on our last deals, and also to provide additional insight on how these transactions fit into our equity story. 
If we now move to Slide 12, you can see a summary of recent activity, 261 towers from Protelindo, the acquisition of Commscon in Italy, an agreement with Bouygues to add up to 500 towers in France. And our recent acquisition of Shere Group which added to our already significant portfolio allow us to become one of the key players worldwide. 
These deals represent the initial steps into very attractive markets and allow us to achieve a more focused portfolio of services, ready to capture additional growth. Most importantly, this transaction allows us to diversify into countries with a strong credit rating, and strengthen our relationship with a wider array of blue-chip clients, therefore, improving our business risk profile. 
Moving to Slide 13. You can see here a table that shows how to think about cash flow generation from our recent acquisition. The cash conversion rate from EBITDA into recurrent levered free cash flow is 70%. And the new deals are expected to generate EUR 27 million on a full year basis or, in other words, around 15% of the recurrent levered free cash flow generated in 2015. And all this has been achieved with an extremely efficient capital structure and by applying our strict investment criteria. 
On Slide 14 show more details on the Dutch operation of our last transaction. I would like to emphasize that we are consolidating our presence in the country, while improving our industrial profile by strengthening our relationship with clients. 
Also, in Slide 15, we offer a summary of our operations in the U.K. It is important to highlight that by acquiring Shere Group, Cellnex takes its first step into a country with a very strong economy, with the objective to continue identifying and executing new work opportunities and replicating, therefore, our successful international expansion strategy. 
And finally, Slide 17, just on closing remarks before opening for questions. Again, a solid set of results, showing strong financials and executed value accretive transactions. We have also issued our second bond in order to achieve even more efficient capital structure, first steps to becoming the European leader in the distributed antenna system. And finally, we still keep execution capacity to continue growing while improving our  business risk profile. 
So with this, I would like to open the line to answer your questions.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Giles Thorne from Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Giles Thorne from Jefferies.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Giles Thorne from Jefferies. I have 3 questions, please. Yesterday, we had American Tower announce a joint venture with the Dutch pension fund, PGGM, where it's going to transfer its German operation into new vehicle and then sell the stake to P
componenttext: Yes, it's Giles Thorne from Jefferies. I have 3 questions, please. Yesterday, we had American Tower announce a joint venture with the Dutch pension fund, PGGM, where it's going to transfer its German operation into new vehicle and then sell the stake to PGGM. In my mind, this sends mixed signals around AMT's ambitions in Europe. On the one hand, it's a pullback. But at same time, it introduced what's probably an energized new partner for that business. So it'd be interesting to hear your perspective. Do you see M&A competition increasing from here? Secondly, I wanted to pick up on some of the financial problems RTVE is having in Spain. The local press has reported on the SCPI. Reporter says RTVE needs dramatic action to avoid failing. Is there any risk to your pricing power for multiplex capacity when that comes up for renewal? And then, lastly, turning to the Shere acquisition in the U.K. market. The U.K. market's quite unique in so much that it's perhaps the most progressive mobile network-sharing market of anywhere in Europe in the form of MBNL and CTIL. We have large and progressive quasi-independent tower companies. Given this unique market structure, how is the organic growth outlook in the U.K.? Any easier or any harder compared to your other markets? That was it.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Well, regarding your first question, American Tower, yes, you are right. I mean, yesterday, we acknowledged that American Tower is doing a joint venture with PPGM (sic) [PGGM]. And we -- it's not the first time that American Tower is
componenttext: Thank you very much. Well, regarding your first question, American Tower, yes, you are right. I mean, yesterday, we acknowledged that American Tower is doing a joint venture with PPGM (sic) [PGGM]. And we -- it's not the first time that American Tower is in Europe, so it's not the first movement that -- they have been in Europe since 2012, the beginning. We have been competing with American Tower in -- I think in the main deals in Europe. So again, I think that American Tower is really interested in Europe. So -- and they are doing their strategy moves, movements and taking the position. But nothing new, to be honest, nothing new apart from that they are monetizing parts of their assets. But it remain interest -- and this, at the end of the day, reflects the main -- I mean, the attractiveness of the European market. I think that we have to go beyond on the fact -- if American Tower -- if there's -- all the leaders looking at Europe. If all this happens is because there is a value in this market. And Cellnex is a first mover here. So of course, and there will be more movement. So we are ready to work. We are ready to go beyond what is set up. As you said in the last question, U.K. market is a challenging market. Of course, it is. But also, they are very important opportunities -- DAS systems, no? And we have been very vocal here. We really believe we can -- we have something to say in this dynamic British market. And there are niches of opportunity that, of course, we are going to work out in detail. And it's now. And of course, there are sharing programs that are not [ph] worth sharing. But there are also opportunities maybe through organic growth, pure organic growth, not only the possibility to acquire towers. You talked about Radiotelevisión Española. Well, since year 2000, I think, Radiotelevisión Española has had programs. But I have not been able to see any different situation since then, to be honest. This is a public TV. You know the Spanish state, how it is performing for the bad and for the good, and is one of our main clients. And I can tell you something, we will be there to help and to work with our client so that we'll reach other ways with -- ask any other client, we win agreements. But we don't have this position being white or black. It's nothing new for us. It's our normal way of somehow reacting and working.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from Domenico Ghilotti from Equita.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A few questions. The first, if you could clarify the -- in the guidance when you are referring to Q4 EBITDA being quite similar to Q3. So if you mean organically or if you are also including the M&A contribution? And the second question is on the network
componenttext: A few questions. The first, if you could clarify the -- in the guidance when you are referring to Q4 EBITDA being quite similar to Q3. So if you mean organically or if you are also including the M&A contribution? And the second question is on the network service performance that was quite up quarter-on-quarter in Q3. I can't understand -- there is something. So what is behind this trend? Is this recurrent? And then third question is on your French operations. I was expecting a faster ramp-up, while I saw that was basically not contributing to top line. And also, the number of towers was below my expectation compared to the initial bunch that you were expected to buy. So if you can also clarify on this.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Domenico, this is Juan. So first of all, on the guidance, all the assumptions we shared at the beginning of the year are still valid. Obviously, the cost of the execution of M&A, now we have additional building blocks, and we are not referring to an
componenttext: Sure. Domenico, this is Juan. So first of all, on the guidance, all the assumptions we shared at the beginning of the year are still valid. Obviously, the cost of the execution of M&A, now we have additional building blocks, and we are not referring to any single figure for the end of the year. So basically, the way we are taking our guidance here is everything we said at the beginning of the year is still valid. And market consensus before M&A during the year is valid, and we will look to increase that. And then on top of that, we should be expecting the proportional portion of the money contribution within the year, which is in line with the magnitude we have raised with the market. And then in terms of network services and others, well, this is an area where, for example, we have trading, which is the sale of equipment, and that provides with some volatility in the performance quarter-on-quarter. So this is the explanation of the performance for the period. And finally, on France, bear in mind that we closed the first batch of towers at the beginning -- sorry, at the end of the period. So it's just a few days of contribution in the quarter. And also, the number of towers are, today, 113. And then we are also expecting the remaining part of the 230 batch will be contributing to our figures the moment we receive the waiver from our landlords. So that is expected to happen during the coming weeks, and that has nothing to do with the second batch of the agreement. So 230 that has already been closed, 113 that was already contributing, and we are expecting to integrate the remaining part of that state over the coming weeks.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Parin Shah from Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question comes from Parin Shah from Bank of America.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Parin Shah from Bank of America. I have 3 for you. The first relates to American Tower. What I want to ask was, in terms of your criteria in relation to acquisition targets, do you think that your, should we say, guidelines are more or less strict th
componenttext: It's Parin Shah from Bank of America. I have 3 for you. The first relates to American Tower. What I want to ask was, in terms of your criteria in relation to acquisition targets, do you think that your, should we say, guidelines are more or less strict than to someone like American Tower who I understand has a global mandate to acquisitions? The second question is, do you believe that Cellnex might be a target for American Tower themselves, particularly in the context of the sizable stake that Alberta still retains in your company? And the third question is just on Italy. In terms of the net adds in the quarter, what proportion were actually from MNOs? And what proportion were attributable to fixed wireless players and things like that?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you for your questions. Well, the 2 first questions, at the end of the day, is about American Tower. And for me, it's difficult to answer, but I would try to give you my point of view, which is, yes, our point of view. I don't know who is more
componenttext: Okay. Thank you for your questions. Well, the 2 first questions, at the end of the day, is about American Tower. And for me, it's difficult to answer, but I would try to give you my point of view, which is, yes, our point of view. I don't know who is more strict -- if American Tower or Cellnex, to be honest. For me, and as a CFO, it will be very difficult to estimate the risk in Nigeria. It's for me, it would be very difficult. So I don't know which data I could estimate. I don't know. I don't know how it can -- FX. So there are many things when comparing how strict from an M&A perspective we are. It's difficult to know exactly point-by-point. What I can tell you is that we are focused on long-term contracts. We are focused on reducing FX risk. We are focused on mature economies. And therefore, all these together defines M&A and some requirements, which has to be filled. So it's difficult to compare. It's my question -- my answer to that question. Your second question, which is about American Tower, well, again, we can be a target or not. It's something that should be answered by American Tower. What I can tell you is that the European market, even though it's mature, even though there is no FX raised and even though maybe inflation is not very high, even though everything seems to be interesting and there are lot of value to unlock. And again, Cellnex will be there to be the first to unlock this value for our shareholders. And then regarding Italy, maybe [indiscernible] you are better positioned than me to answer.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me provide you with a wider answer in the [indiscernible]. So we have a full picture for spend in Italy and Spain. On the new box generated in the quarter, I would say that 50% are coming from traditional MNOs and 50% are coming from alternative
componenttext: Yes. Let me provide you with a wider answer in the [indiscernible]. So we have a full picture for spend in Italy and Spain. On the new box generated in the quarter, I would say that 50% are coming from traditional MNOs and 50% are coming from alternative operators. And I'm talking here about fixed broadband. In the case of Italy, again, looking at new PoPs in the quarter, maybe the proportion is 40% for traditional MNOs, 60% for alternative operators.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Could I just clarify, on the grid in Italy, do you see in the coming quarters any pickup in MNO activity on your portfolio?
componenttext: Great. Could I just clarify, on the grid in Italy, do you see in the coming quarters any pickup in MNO activity on your portfolio?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, we are maintaining our view. We have provided at the beginning of the year, a 3%, 4% range in order to -- in terms of new box generated in the year. And we have no indication, by which we should be changing.
componenttext: I would say, we are maintaining our view. We have provided at the beginning of the year, a 3%, 4% range in order to -- in terms of new box generated in the year. And we have no indication, by which we should be changing.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Fernando Cordero from Banco Santander.
componenttext: The next question comes from Fernando Cordero from Banco Santander.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for taking my 2 questions. And the first one is, again, related with M&A. I would like to know what are your views regarding the potential firepower that the companies still have in [indiscernible] use [ph] at current state? And the second question
componenttext: Thanks for taking my 2 questions. And the first one is, again, related with M&A. I would like to know what are your views regarding the potential firepower that the companies still have in [indiscernible] use [ph] at current state? And the second question is related with network services business line. And I would like to know, in order also to understand the volatility, I would like to know what is the -- excluding these equipment trading activities, what is the average duration of the current contracts in network services? For example, considering that you have recently renewed one of the most important one, where do we buy the services? And the third question is I'm just trying to understand if there is a new trend behind some of the news that we have recently heard in the Spain, particularly in the sense of the recent agreement between MásMóvil and Orange, in which MásMóvil [indiscernible] is reaching a tower-sharing agreement with Orange. In that sense, are you seeing that? And the MNOs are looking for -- organically, to struck value from the tower assets or, in other words, to become tower companies? Or is it just like, for example, disagreement between Yoigo and Orange is just a part of a larger [indiscernible] agreement [indiscernible] not as a pure, how can I say, activity related with the towers. Just to understand if MNOs could become even a competitor for the independent tower companies.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fernando, regarding M&A firepower, well, the firepower, it's defined by several factors, no? First of all, our capacity to grow organically. Second, where we invest and what kind of contract we get from this investment, no? So it is not the same des
componenttext: Okay. Fernando, regarding M&A firepower, well, the firepower, it's defined by several factors, no? First of all, our capacity to grow organically. Second, where we invest and what kind of contract we get from this investment, no? So it is not the same destiny in one country, which is for instance, BBB than is AAA because the business risk profile changes significantly. So you know, there are other factors, things that change that firepower. So I've seen that as of today, we have headroom to grow in. How much, it depends on the characteristic. If, for instance, we take a deal, which is backlog, huge backlog, with synergies and we will have more headroom. So it's something we have to go case-by-case. What I can tell you is that from an M&A perspective, what we try to execute our deals that from an investment point of view makes sense, generating value and have long-term contract with cash flow visibility, which can diversify our risks. So this depends on a case-by-case basis. We have been investing until today, let's say, EUR 600 million. And as you can see, our ratings have not changed at all. So this can give you -- not anything. I mean, not even outlook. So -- and you can see that this is somehow -- it's because we improve also all the parameters. Regarding the network services and others, maybe, Juan, you can help me?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Fernando. Well, you know that within this business line, we have a bunch of sub-activities. We have an adjacent communications, connectivity operations and maintenance. So it's -- the characteristics of the contracts are different across the services
componenttext: Yes, Fernando. Well, you know that within this business line, we have a bunch of sub-activities. We have an adjacent communications, connectivity operations and maintenance. So it's -- the characteristics of the contracts are different across the services. But I would say, on average, you can assume a 4-5 years of contract duration.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you were talking about MásMóvil, Orange. And well, as far as we know, it's -- Yoigo had before a contract with Telefonica regarding a roaming agreement, not a national roaming agreement. Now it seems, and we say it seems because we do not have
componenttext: And then you were talking about MásMóvil, Orange. And well, as far as we know, it's -- Yoigo had before a contract with Telefonica regarding a roaming agreement, not a national roaming agreement. Now it seems, and we say it seems because we do not have the info, it seems that this contract is going to change from one supplier to another supplier -- that you said, yes, this Orange, fine. I don't know what has changed in this game yet. We are open to discuss all the configurations that is -- can have consequence. And we are open also to discuss the passive infrastructure. But please take into account that the network and this roaming agreement is about active -- probably speaking, is the active part of agreement. And we are much more focused on the passive part of the infrastructure. So I don't see yet a big change here. And what I can tell you is that the company is working in different angles and with different clients.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. My point was, particularly on this agreement between Orange and Yoigo, is that Orange is going to provide passive infrastructure services to Yoigo or Yoigo's network expansion. In that sense, I would like to know if you are foreseeing or if you are se
componenttext: No. My point was, particularly on this agreement between Orange and Yoigo, is that Orange is going to provide passive infrastructure services to Yoigo or Yoigo's network expansion. In that sense, I would like to know if you are foreseeing or if you are seeing in the market more activity from the part of MNOs having already tower assets offering actively these assets to third parties. That is, I would say, the end of that I will say -- was also trying to see your insights there?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, Fernando. It's something that we have not seen in other -- well, in fact, in this situation, we are working. We are trying to understand the situation to see what angle we can contribute and think change on a country-by-country basis. So the key
componenttext: Yes. No, Fernando. It's something that we have not seen in other -- well, in fact, in this situation, we are working. We are trying to understand the situation to see what angle we can contribute and think change on a country-by-country basis. So the key point here is to understand the business model that a company of us, Cellnex, can supply in this environment. But it depends on our client needs, how a client wants to develop their rollout. So we are open to discuss. We are open to see and change -- country-by-country change. But for us, it's not an issue. It's just how we adapt to the situation.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Mark Murphy from Macquarie.
componenttext: The next question comes from Mark Murphy from Macquarie.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark Murphy from Macquarie here. Number one, I just wondered if you had any idea of Iliad launch? I know you've had discussions with Iliad on their Italian move. I was wondering if you have any knowledge you could share in terms of when they might launch
componenttext: Mark Murphy from Macquarie here. Number one, I just wondered if you had any idea of Iliad launch? I know you've had discussions with Iliad on their Italian move. I was wondering if you have any knowledge you could share in terms of when they might launch and what sort of strategy they may deploy? Second question is just in terms of your presentation, you highlight new opportunities from the consolidation of the fourth mobile operator all across Europe. And are you talking specifically here where a third and fourth come together? Are you saying more where fourth mobile operator maybe goes for a CapEx line approach, maybe out of Bouygues, whey they're considering to sell towers and use this sort of tower-sharing model. And then just a last quick question, if you don't mind. On rental costs, there's been a very small creep in Spain initially, but it makes me wonder how you're progressing in terms of your site renegotiation strategy. I remember you were targeting 5,000 sites for renegotiation, predominantly in Italy.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Juan. Well, on the year-ago quarter, we noticed that the spectrum in order to launch commercial operations in Italy is going to be produced by Iliad during the second half of 2017. So that's the -- at least, we should be expecting the Iliad
componenttext: Mark, this is Juan. Well, on the year-ago quarter, we noticed that the spectrum in order to launch commercial operations in Italy is going to be produced by Iliad during the second half of 2017. So that's the -- at least, we should be expecting the Iliad to start their business in the country. So from there, depending on how they want to deploy the network. If there are opportunities to capture, obviously, we will be talking to them. So -- but in any case, it's not an opportunity to be materialized in the very short term, as the company has not even started commercial operations in the country. On the 4th operator awarding we've used in the presentation, that is linked to Iliad. And also, that is linked to MásMóvil in -- sorry, Iliad in Italy and MásMóvil in Spain. Basically, what they're trying to say here is that, at the moment, we'll find an opportunity to do business with a fourth operator willing to deploy our network. We will be willing to offer our portfolio and try to capture organic growth from them. So we have specifically having in mind these 2 opportunities, both in Italy and in Spain. And your third question, rental cost, bear in mind that on the rents line in our P&L, it's not the [indiscernible] we have. We also have the expenses associated with our car fleet, satellite cost, connectivity cost if we use third-party fiber. So we believe our ground lease cost are pretty well contained. The slight increase is due to some other lines contributing to this trend cost. And we are on track with our efficiency program. Hopefully, we can provide more visibility on the specific savings we are achieving. You can see that on the amount of money expansion on CapEx, we are about in important resources to our cost [indiscernible] program. So everything is on track.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Henrik Herbst from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question comes from Henrik Herbst from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on Commscon and your plans there. Obviously, it's quite a rough period of rollout of the new DAS nodes. And I was just wondering if you could give a little bit of color in terms of at what rate -- I mean, maybe that's just a one
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on Commscon and your plans there. Obviously, it's quite a rough period of rollout of the new DAS nodes. And I was just wondering if you could give a little bit of color in terms of at what rate -- I mean, maybe that's just a one-off, and the rollout rate will slow down as we go along? And then in terms of -- is that rollouts essentially for one of the operators or is that just you just billing it and then you go ahead and try to sell it? The other question is, in terms of the economics of these DAS nodes, if you can give anything in terms how many tenants you've got at the moment? And what rates do you get from your tenants? And then I've got another question as well. In terms of the energy passed through revenues you've got in Spain on the Telecom Site Rental, how much of the Telecom Site Rental revenues is DAS?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Henrik, on the Commscon rollout, basically, the increase versus the initial figure that we provided in H1 is because of organic growth that Commscon has been able to generate. And we are mainly talking about new projects, very small projects. But it's not
componenttext: Henrik, on the Commscon rollout, basically, the increase versus the initial figure that we provided in H1 is because of organic growth that Commscon has been able to generate. And we are mainly talking about new projects, very small projects. But it's not because of new nodes or additional nodes being associated with specific MNOs, simply Commscon being able to generate business in new locations in the north of Italy. Then, on the economics of this business, we are still working on that in a sense that we are working on a group-wide business plan. So at some point in the short term, we will provide more color on how we see the economics of DAS business portfolio whole of the Cellnex Group. Bear in mind that the revenue per node might change depending on the involvement of the client on the development of the network. So if it's Commscon deploying the whole CapEx, we might be able to achieve higher revenue per node if the -- if any owner, for example, is willing to co-invest with Commscon also the associated fees of solo work. So we have a wider range of possibilities within this business model. Then on the pass-through, we are not providing the breakdown in terms of what is exactly the amount of pass-throughs coming on the annual accounts. We are giving that figure for the full year. Basically, bear in mind that in some cases, we don't have dedicated counters within some shelters. So it's a matter of negotiating with the customer on an operating basis, on the adjustments to be made on the pass-through cost associated with electricity. So it is true that in this case, in this quarter for Spain, there have been some adjustments to the star contributor to this revenue space. And this is why the performance for the quarter is flat, offsetting the pure organic growth generated in the given period. But you have to look at from an EBITDA perspective that the growth is coming because it is -- you cannot only see the revenues, you can see -- you have to see also the attached OpEx. So if you have this somehow split of revenues and cost associated, you would be able to see that the EBITDA is coming anyway.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. Can I just follow up? So what tenancy ratio do you have on your current DAS nodes, please?
componenttext: That's great. Can I just follow up? So what tenancy ratio do you have on your current DAS nodes, please?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will say to you, that's 3. I mean, it's 3 in general. So you have, in Page 21, a slide that explains how this works, conceptually speaking. This is the business model that we will try to develop further in the presentation for the full year. And you can
componenttext: I will say to you, that's 3. I mean, it's 3 in general. So you have, in Page 21, a slide that explains how this works, conceptually speaking. This is the business model that we will try to develop further in the presentation for the full year. And you can see that the system how it works in the middle of the page. And here we implement 3, MNO 1, MNO 2, MNO 3. This is not by chance. This is because it's the typical system that we tend to implement, okay? And by the way, this is a very interesting field, in which we expect high growth in the next quarters. When we talk about defining the business model, we are aware that this is something that we have the opportunity to shape in Europe. And this is a unique opportunity. And we are somehow elaborating this, although we have strong views that we have to be prudent to share at the right time.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Patrick Basiewicz from Olivetree.
componenttext: The next question comes from Patrick Basiewicz from Olivetree.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 3. The first one is relating to the troubles travels of Telefonica and their failed Telxius IPO. There were press reports that you would be interested in Telxius. I presumed the reports sort of meant to say that you'd be interested in some of the t
componenttext: I have 3. The first one is relating to the troubles travels of Telefonica and their failed Telxius IPO. There were press reports that you would be interested in Telxius. I presumed the reports sort of meant to say that you'd be interested in some of the towers that Telefonica has. Can you maybe clarify exactly what was being applied there? And my second question relates to something quite abstract, which is broadband or Wi-Fi on airplanes. We know that Inmarsat has a network which is part terrestrial, part satellite, and Verizon is thinking of providing Wi-Fi on the planes via their spectrum. Is this something you're seeing as an opportunity in terms of additional tenancy on your towers throughout Europe? And my third and final question relates to the entrance of Iliad into the Italian market. And they are known for a relatively rapid rollout of PoPs in the markets they enter into. My question is, is there any limits to how fast they could deploy the network? Or how fast do you think you could deploy the network if once they enter Italy proper?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you for your questions. I mean, regarding Telxius, I have no comment. I mean, it's something that goes beyond our scope. Regarding your second question, which is Wi-Fis and airplanes, this is -- we are aware of this, and we also think that the
componenttext: Okay. Thank you for your questions. I mean, regarding Telxius, I have no comment. I mean, it's something that goes beyond our scope. Regarding your second question, which is Wi-Fis and airplanes, this is -- we are aware of this, and we also think that they are pretty little BTS for this kind of services. It is true that internally, this is one of the projects we have been assessing. And we keep two eyes on it. And again, this is like the business model of DAS. It has to be defined, and Cellnex is well-positioned to capture value. And finally, you've been talking about Iliad. Well, again, this question could be asked to somehow better Iliad to Cellnex. But the thing is that we are ready to follow the indication of our client. If they really want to deploy before or later, I don't know, we'll be there to make this feasible. And we are not a bottleneck at the end of the day. We -- this is important. We work with all of our clients on a very confidential basis. And it's not us who will -- as to somehow define this kind of strategies.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Nelson Bernardino from Haitong.
componenttext: The next question comes from Nelson Bernardino from Haitong.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of them have been answered. I just have one left. I was expecting a little bit of increase in revenues from broadcasting since the new channels only started broadcasting in late April. But they were flat year-on-year. Was this because they were alrea
componenttext: Most of them have been answered. I just have one left. I was expecting a little bit of increase in revenues from broadcasting since the new channels only started broadcasting in late April. But they were flat year-on-year. Was this because they were already contributing revenue throughout the quarter? And is the EUR 61 million we should expect going forward maybe updated for inflation?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nelson, this is Juan. Actually, the new -- the 63 channels were switched at the beginning of April. So we saw a full contribution during Q2. That's exactly what we are seeing in Q3. And that should be taken as a reference for the coming quarters. Okay? Th
componenttext: Nelson, this is Juan. Actually, the new -- the 63 channels were switched at the beginning of April. So we saw a full contribution during Q2. That's exactly what we are seeing in Q3. And that should be taken as a reference for the coming quarters. Okay? They were not switched on late April. That was in the beginning. So that's why Q3 on a standalone basis is almost spot on with Q2.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Germán García from JB Capital.
componenttext: The next question comes from Germán García from JB Capital.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: José Manuel and Juan, I have 2 questions. First one is on the efficiency plan. I would like to know if you can confirm to us that EUR 2 million to EUR 3 million savings for 2016 on top of the EUR 22 million of the total program? And which one could be th
componenttext: José Manuel and Juan, I have 2 questions. First one is on the efficiency plan. I would like to know if you can confirm to us that EUR 2 million to EUR 3 million savings for 2016 on top of the EUR 22 million of the total program? And which one could be the -- your best guess for the year '17 in terms of savings? And the second one is if you are still interested in the further operations in the French market, which could be of a larger size than the ones already accomplished?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Germán, for your questions. For your question regarding efficiencies, in the Excel sheet you will find better detail than what I'm going to tell you. But broadly speaking, EUR 15 million, 1-5, of investment as of today was of September 30, and
componenttext: Thank you, Germán, for your questions. For your question regarding efficiencies, in the Excel sheet you will find better detail than what I'm going to tell you. But broadly speaking, EUR 15 million, 1-5, of investment as of today was of September 30, and with EUR 2 million of savings. And again, you talk about what's going to happen in 2017, let us review all the guideline for 2017 in the next quarter when we have the visibility of the full year. However, I can tell you that this program is working very well, very, very well. And also, you were raising a point regarding the French market. Yes, the French market is also a very interesting market in Europe. And as you know, there are several -- one in 5 businesses have [ph] [indiscernible] and sanction [ph] going on right now. And we'll have the mandate to assess all opportunities in, let's say, Western Europe. And therefore, we're seeing these opportunity also. But nothing else. I mean, we are following the rules of the game or the setups. So, yes, yes about that.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: I have 2 questions, if I may. On one hand, could you provide us a bit of an update on the status of the rural site's rollout? And then, secondly, could you give us a bit more color on what opportunities do you see in the U.K.? Is it more on the build to suit opportunity coming from the network expansion that some of the MNOs are taking, for instance like EI rolling out 4G? Or is it more an inorganic opportunity from an MNO or another independent company?

componenttext: Okay. Thank you. Let's just start by the second question. The U.K. market has some specificities, as we were saying before. And I think we have a good platform, enough platform to continue growing organically speaking and especially regarding distributed antenna systems. So this is something we are really focused on. So as you can see, maybe it's more organic than inorganic, at least in the short term, okay? This is the main characteristic of the U.K. market. And your first question, I have not been able to understand well. So can you repeat?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from Luigi Minerva from HSBC.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Three questions, which are a bit on the big picture. Well, the first one is your view about new technologies like, for example, the use of millimeter waves by some U.S. operators to complete the fiber deployment. So rather than doing it wireline over the
componenttext: Three questions, which are a bit on the big picture. Well, the first one is your view about new technologies like, for example, the use of millimeter waves by some U.S. operators to complete the fiber deployment. So rather than doing it wireline over the very last part, they use effectively a wireless technology. And I was wondering if you see this as a profitable opportunity, a business opportunity for you? Also, in Europe, has -- they will do it also here in due course, the various MNOs. The second question is about buying lands, which is something that one of your peers -- or competitors, rather -- is doing in Italy. Is it something that you're interested in? And more broadly, just going back to one of the points from your prospectus, whether medium term you have an ambition to become a real estate investment trust. And thirdly, just an update on your views about backhaul as an opportunity and the CapEx it will involve, and whether you see -- feel a good business case there?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Luigi, this is Juan. On your first question, I would say that we are monitoring closely, monitoring any  original challenge, where we can capture a new organic opportunity. In this case, we are doing something similar for a telecom operator here in Spain.
componenttext: Luigi, this is Juan. On your first question, I would say that we are monitoring closely, monitoring any  original challenge, where we can capture a new organic opportunity. In this case, we are doing something similar for a telecom operator here in Spain. What we are doing is connectivity services at the smallest scale. We are providing -- make a way for connectivity, and that is included today in the network services and others business line. So [indiscernible] how we are pursuing these organic opportunities where we'll find them. But today we see them as a small opportunity for us so far.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your second question was about nonacquisition [ph] program in Italy. Of course -- I mean, of course, we have discussed advanced program and, on top of that, the opportunity to acquire land. And we are already finishing the pilot. And I don't think that we
componenttext: Your second question was about nonacquisition [ph] program in Italy. Of course -- I mean, of course, we have discussed advanced program and, on top of that, the opportunity to acquire land. And we are already finishing the pilot. And I don't think that we'll be -- further interesting source of value for our shareholders. But yes, we believe we have headroom here. And your final question was about backhaul. Again, and I know I'm sorry for repeating this as we cannot share all the details and all the stuff here, as clients require, from time to time, this kind of silence or working prudent. But yes, we are pursuing the opportunity. We are also developing the business model. I'm pretty sure that we'll be able to explain at some point in detail. I think Cellnex, the good thing is that as we are not a real estate company, we are an infrastructure company, open to follow what our clients needs and how our clients' needs evolve. And you have raised a very interesting question. And because our clients evolve, so we have to evolve. And we have the capacities. And also, we are already testing this to be, again, the first mover in the European arena.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a few more questions left. The 2 are very specific. The third, it's a bit big picture, but relates to your business model. This particular one, it's on Page 10. You show a breakdown in organic growth, in levered free cash flow putout that we could
componenttext: I have a few more questions left. The 2 are very specific. The third, it's a bit big picture, but relates to your business model. This particular one, it's on Page 10. You show a breakdown in organic growth, in levered free cash flow putout that we could expect going forward for next year above 20%. Now if I do the numbers in terms of what we expect from the generation, from the new acquisition, it looks that through M&A, you should grow your -- levered free cash flow by around 14%. But of course, you do already the consolidated sum of this cash this year. So the question is, if you can give a breakdown for next year of this above 20% growth you expect on levered free cash flow, how much will be organic and how much will be through M&A for the acquisition you've already seen it? The second one, it's -- I'm going into the specifics of your number. In organic growth, the PoPs, you actually recorded the highest growth, both in Spain and in Italy. Now I remember during the IPO and afterwards, you guys have been passionate saying that the telco business model in Europe is new. We need time. We have to convince MNOs. But over time, we believe that it could be a ramp-up. Is this a ramp-up you believe is happening now or you're going to adjust the one-off and potentially go back to what we've seen in previous quarters? And the third one, it's a big picture, but because -- not in the sector adjustment, just on your business model. You're bidding for the towers that Antin is putting for sale. They actually mentioned during the call. But obviously, your chairman has been pretty vocal. Now early this year, you have been involved in the Inwit. And at that stage, you showed us that you were prepared to go to a gearing of almost 6x net EBITDA. Now, things do change in the credit market. Things do change in the market generally. So I was wondering if that 6x is still valid? And that's not the big -- the sort of your biggest modeled. I'm still wondering, do you really need to have a broadcasting business in Spain? Which sort of synergies do you basically extract? Of course, people can say that you've got a high tenancy ratio in Spain than in Italy, but that's because you bought a lot of ad covers from the JV. So I was just wondering, there could be, also going forward, the possibility of reviewing your business model and focusing more on tower rental rather than just on the average [ph] that you have at the moment and potentially see the broadcasting as a way to cash it in?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ottavio, you have raised so many points that you will have to help me to remember all of them. So a little, step-by-step. And I don't know. The first that you -- one of the...
componenttext: Ottavio, you have raised so many points that you will have to help me to remember all of them. So a little, step-by-step. And I don't know. The first that you -- one of the...

componenttext: The breakdown of the growth, yes.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the breakdown of the growth. Now in Page 10, what we said to you is not -- is what we expect for full year in 2016 and from accountancy -- accounting basis. So taking into account that one business will start generating EBITDA. For instance, Protelin
componenttext: Yes, the breakdown of the growth. Now in Page 10, what we said to you is not -- is what we expect for full year in 2016 and from accountancy -- accounting basis. So taking into account that one business will start generating EBITDA. For instance, Protelindo towers with a [indiscernible] are generating EBITDA for us since July 1. And maybe the French towers are starting to work since late September, and Shere Group will start to work since late October, something like that. So the thing is that, obviously, this -- when we talk here about over 20% when compared to 2015, broadly speaking, its minority feed belongs to organic growth. It does not belong to M&A, okay? So this is the first point. It's important to see this. And this is very linked to the follow -- one of the other questions you have raised, which was about a financing strategy, no? Financing strategy is not the same when you are maybe a company which is based in Spain and with win in Italy -- or in Italy with the Galata, sorry. And then you become more diversified with new clients and how we are trying to diversify or to increase our business risk profile. So this changed the metrics. And this changes the 6x, the 5x. It changed everything. So when you say we can raise to 6x, my answer is, yes, as long as our business risk profile increases. As long as from a credit perspective we can say, "Okay. Even though the metric can be a little bit challenging, from a business risk profile, the company can support further leverage." So the question is, if we reach 6x, how we'll deleverage later? We delevered enough more quickly a way than before? If the answer is yes, then the problem is not 6x. It's how you get to the new target in 2017, '18 or '19. So it's a little bit sophisticated more than before. So we can get to 6x, the answer is yes. It depends on the business risk profile and the delever -- the delevering profile of the company after the acquisition. So you have to be done on a base-by-base cases (sic) [case-by-case basis]. But the point here is we'll do the most efficient structure to protect our shareholders and also to be eligible because, today, being eligible has a value percent. What else? You raised the PoPs question, I don't know if it was the 2 -- the second or the third, but it was in the middle. PoPs question, yes, you are right when you said that at the moment of the IPO, we were saying that the PoPs growth was not going to be steady in time and was going to be leaner. The PoPs growth can have some jumps maybe. So we need some -- I don't know how you say it in English -- or choppy, I think you say that can be a little bumpy. Bumps. And that's true. However, also in different Q results, we have been vocal about this. Witnessing that 3% is a good level of growth in terms of PoPs. And the sources of this can be several. It can be, for instance, natural organic growth. So more multi-tenancy or can be, for instance, more commissioning. But if we think 3% is sustainable, and we'll have to fight for it as a company, at least. And then you were suggesting, to be honest, the last question for me was difficult to understand, to follow, so you can...

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. So the last question is basically regarding your business model. You are more than an exception than the rule in terms of your business model. You have broadcasting and tower site rental on the same company. And this comes from history because,
componenttext: Yes, okay. So the last question is basically regarding your business model. You are more than an exception than the rule in terms of your business model. You have broadcasting and tower site rental on the same company. And this comes from history because, of course, the broadcasting was the historical business and then you diversified the way. Now that you actually still keep growing, and of course, there is limit up to how much the balance sheet could be geared up, consider that they -- what you said earlier. So I was wondering, first of all, what of sort synergies are we talking about to keep that broadcasting business in-house? And I said, I can see the high tenancy ratios you have in Spain, but most of them come from because you bought towers with already 2 tenants. So what else do we have to talk in terms of synergies? And second, do you think -- and obviously the big pictures. Do you think that the business will look like this within 5, 10 years, still a hybrid between broadcasting and tower site rental? Hopefully, that's now more clear.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Thank you. Now I did understand, yes. First of all, many of our broadcasting towers has Telecom Site Rental PoPs. And you -- I remember, you were in the IPO and you -- we explained at that moment. And this information is available in the website or at
componenttext: No. Thank you. Now I did understand, yes. First of all, many of our broadcasting towers has Telecom Site Rental PoPs. And you -- I remember, you were in the IPO and you -- we explained at that moment. And this information is available in the website or at least in the -- for yet or no. So the reason's very clear. I mean, starting from the revenues and starting for the clients, our broadcasting tower can give service to the telecom -- to MNOs. So this is question A. Second, broadcasting for us is a must -- sorry, is an end or it is a mean. For us, broadcasting is a mean. Broadcasting allows us to generate somehow visibility in our cash flows to keep our relationship with very important clients, which whom we can, as you were suggesting, develop further the broadcasting. You were talking about hybrid services that we are also targeting. And we would like to be there as a first mover again to adapt the company to the new situation. But the most important synergy is not this one. The most important is the first one. The most important synergy is that we have -- somehow, we have the experience, all the experience learned from broadcasting to have a different angle in Telecom Site Rental. We are managing -- in the broadcasting, we are managing -- in the value chain, we are managing much more steps of these value chains. And this allow us to adapt our client when, for instance, when you raised the point of what about fiber to the tower? What about the DAS? In the DAS -- and you have this in Page 25 or 21. You can see here we are -- in the DAS system, we are already managing asset equipment. You are better positioned to do so if you hopped on it with broadcasting, just because the team is prepared. You have engineers. You have many things. So this gives us a real competitive advantage, okay? So synergies is not only revenues. It's not only, what we would say -- as a second point. But also, it's about know-how.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you think this would be a differentiating factor with the other tower companies [indiscernible] of broadcasting business?
componenttext: And you think this would be a differentiating factor with the other tower companies [indiscernible] of broadcasting business?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is. In fact, it is. And also, Ottavio, if we were able to do the IPO at the right moment is because we saw what's happening in our towers at that time. And the result is because there were Telecom Site Rental equipments in our towers, broadcasting towe
componenttext: It is. In fact, it is. And also, Ottavio, if we were able to do the IPO at the right moment is because we saw what's happening in our towers at that time. And the result is because there were Telecom Site Rental equipments in our towers, broadcasting towers at that time. That's the reason why we could acquire back in 2012 the first Telecom Site Rental towers in Spain and later in Italy because we did have a know-how. And for sure, our MSE contracts are developed with all the know-how, all the level of services, all the details required by the clients. And we can even give more ideas. This is coming from something because you have before managed all the value chain.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: The last question comes from Parin Shah from Bank of America.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up. Yes, I think I'm slightly surprised by your defense of the broadcasting business in terms of the comments you've just made. What I wanted to do is maybe focus a bit more on where the risks lie within that portfolio because I think
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up. Yes, I think I'm slightly surprised by your defense of the broadcasting business in terms of the comments you've just made. What I wanted to do is maybe focus a bit more on where the risks lie within that portfolio because I think that's what Ottavio is trying to maybe address. Could you maybe outline in terms of your -- just an update on the strategy. Where does the broadcasting business go when the 700 megahertz goes to mobile? What is your timeframe for that? Is there a T2 upgrade? Do you think there's revenue risk within this broadcast portfolio or not really?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Parin, this is one of the questions we -- recurring, I remember, last Q results. We were talking in detail, and we'll have to be back to the same answer that at that time gave Alex Mestre, our Director of Business. And he was very clear. I mean, we are, a
componenttext: Parin, this is one of the questions we -- recurring, I remember, last Q results. We were talking in detail, and we'll have to be back to the same answer that at that time gave Alex Mestre, our Director of Business. And he was very clear. I mean, we are, as you can imagine, fully aware of this process. And this 700-megahertz suite of DAS has not -- it has not had direct implication on the number of MUXs. So our idea is we think we can readapt the company and the same number of MUXs to another band with another frequency. And that makes sense. So when we expect this? This is not driven by Spain. This is not driven by Cellnex. It's driven by the European Union. And there've been thoughts about this, and we could think and it is stated by the European Commission clearly since 2020, 2022. So nothing new in this part of the business. We don't think that changing the frequency must have an implication on the number of MUXs. Not at all.

componenttext: Okay. I guess, that's clear. I mean, does this mean then -- is think kind of a change in your -- the line you're delivering to the market in terms of willingness to even acquire more broadcasting assets? Because you seem to be suggesting that these assets are pretty desirable.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., Nine Months 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. This is what we said before to Ottavio when he raised the point. Broadcasting, for us, is a mean, not on end, okay? For us, this is what we  were saying. The know-how is the initial part of the deal. But it's not our end. Our end is to consoli
componenttext: No, no, no. This is what we said before to Ottavio when he raised the point. Broadcasting, for us, is a mean, not on end, okay? For us, this is what we  were saying. The know-how is the initial part of the deal. But it's not our end. Our end is to consolidate Cellnex as a telecom server in the entire Europe. And therefore, we are the first mover. But broadcasting is not a mean -- it's not an end in itself.
