headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll try to. I think it is important to maybe do a little bit [indiscernible] on what is the active equipment that we deploy on the DAS. We do not deploy the base station, so the [indiscernible] architecture, and if you go to Page 25, it is clear on
componenttext: Yes, I'll try to. I think it is important to maybe do a little bit [indiscernible] on what is the active equipment that we deploy on the DAS. We do not deploy the base station, so the [indiscernible] architecture, and if you go to Page 25, it is clear on the central picture. And still you see that on the left side of the central picture, there are a few equipments, those are the DTS. So the equipment -- typical equipment that goes into the tower is this one, the one which is on the left, which is the #1, #2 and #3. This -- CapEx in this period from the MNO. So we are not entering, let's say, on to the active equipment at the complexity of a base station. What we do is this DTH [indiscernible] and the nodes and the fiber, we get the signal and the acronym tries to explain what it is. It is a distributed antenna. So we get the signal from DTS and we spread it through a wide coverage area. Instead of having 1 antenna each, for every node we put 10 to 15 antennas. That's the reason that as of today we have something like 900, almost 1,000 nodes, and every node is having 10 to 12 antennas. That's the reason we have up to 12,000 antennas in those systems overall as of today coming from the CommsCon acquisition. So the complexity of sharing the antenna is much less than the complexity of sharing the active agreement. Which then becomes a rank sharing sort of asking. So here, we are not talking about sharing the radio station, we just sharing a distributed antenna which being difficult to deploy in a venue like a stadium, for the [indiscernible] is probably the best way to do it or the only way is to do by sharing. That's the reason that most of the DAS systems as of today are starting from a shared system among different [indiscernible]. But they need to agree amongst themselves to do that. And maybe one has more intelligent in one area, the other in the other, so acting as an enabler of that process makes the situation easier, and where we believe we can get, let's say, an expansion of that business model to other areas. That is not -- it's different electronics, I don't know if I was clear myself. And what maybe your second question that I am not answering or did I answer everything?

componenttext: It is equivalent. In terms of the business model that the MNOs are among themselves giving the overall blended EBITDA for each one of the installation. In that terms, it is equivalent to the tower business, yes.

componenttext: Okay. Now regarding the volume in England, we are interested in continental countries in Europe: Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany. So it's not only U.K. Well, it's U.K., also France, Italy. I mean, all of these countries, European Western countries, generally speaking, of course, we are very interested in. So it's not this country, in fact, it's a group of countries. And then the 2,000 towers theme, again, I think that it was one of the questions of our colleague before. We were saying that this [indiscernible] tower we are working on a daily basis almost with different MNOs, and we are presenting our best alternatives to them. And we do think that eventually that -- no, that finally we'll get it, and we're doing good progress, even though slowly than expected. Why slowly? Because, I mean, the [indiscernible] is open in the market is -- and this requires times, requires to assess different angles, to be patient. And I think as a long-term player, we are very well positioned to capture this market opportunity.

componenttext: Okay, yes. As we have done in Italy and as we have done in the Netherlands and as we have done in France, we do think that it makes sense as a first step in these countries with clients, with new clients for us in our towers, it makes sense to acquire, first of all, a small -- some towers in order to learn, in order to understand opportunities, and then step-by-step, to follow the domino effect that we present in Page 17 of the presentation. So the answer is yes, we think it's prudent, we think it makes sense. And if possible, this is our preferred strategy.

componenttext: Yes, in relation to the fourth. So seems that the #4 is the magic number now. And it is very much welcome from the perspective of the other TowerCo operator. Having said that, let's see how that evolves, okay? Let's see that finally it gets approval in Italy. Also, what we foresee in those additional countries where we are is that there is, yes, a challenger that needs to rapidly deploy coverage and most likely trust to do on their own, because the grant-sharing agreement and growing an [indiscernible] revenue is easy. So for us, yes, it brings in additional opportunity that we are doing, let's say, [indiscernible] in order to capture.

componenttextpreview: The PoP growth in France, as of today, the MNOs we [indiscernible] split the country in 2. We have densely population area and non-dense population area. Dense population area is 42% approximately of the population, and the non-dense 57%. On the non-dense
componenttext: The PoP growth in France, as of today, the MNOs we [indiscernible] split the country in 2. We have densely population area and non-dense population area. Dense population area is 42% approximately of the population, and the non-dense 57%. On the non-dense, this is where the rent-sharing agreements are put in place, for instance, between the telecom and [indiscernible]. In the non-dense -- in the dense area, there are no rent-sharing agreements. But when you view on this dense areas, the number of towers, there is clearly a bigger spread between [indiscernible] who is the operator who has, let's say, the most number of the towers. And then the other MNOs can, in different levels of deployment of sites. And I think you're pointing rightly that it may be having an interest, and this is what we've been also able to discuss during the process -- recent process that we have with them in relation to building more sites, on one side and also Iliad and understanding also that there are some regulatory obligations that for them to finish, let's say, national agreements also to deploy their own network on these areas. So yes, it is another opportunity in terms of having new tenancy in especially on these dense areas.

componenttext: Just got one additional question, if I could further ask. Just on the small cells, [indiscernible] Italian company, and I guess many might have thought the succession of intended to kind of [indiscernible] networks in Italy where there might be some potential demand. I guess, are you thinking then actually in multiple European countries, there is demand for small cells and what kind of time frame do you think this to actually materialize this?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Basically, the interest is to learn on this slightly different market. And as you called, this could be expanded, because yes, we feel, let's say, in our market analysis, the demand for densification. And then maybe [indiscernible] results were to differe
componenttext: Basically, the interest is to learn on this slightly different market. And as you called, this could be expanded, because yes, we feel, let's say, in our market analysis, the demand for densification. And then maybe [indiscernible] results were to differentiate between that and the small cells. Small cells is a very small densification. As we try to explain in our documentation, it is a distributed antenna where the densification is something different. In terms of deployment, what we believe is that there is, as of today, an immediate need of DAS for densification. But small cells may come in ways a little bit further down the road, because that is quite also another type of equipment, small cells are still yet to be fully prepared by vendors in the full capacity of sharing among different MNOs. So we understand that there is that demand beyond Italy. And there -- it will come in other ways later on with the small cells. So we can differentiate slightly between these 2 technologies.

componenttext: I've seen that -- yes, you're right, Alex. We have a debate here internally. But my feeling and yes, talking about my view on this is that this is a huge market. So lot of value to create for us.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just follow up on that, because I guess, there is clear first-mover advantage? I mean, once someone signed an agreement to provide the DAS system in a venue, that's it. So I mean, when you think about it, like Ikea, why couldn't you, for example, si
componenttext: Can I just follow up on that, because I guess, there is clear first-mover advantage? I mean, once someone signed an agreement to provide the DAS system in a venue, that's it. So I mean, when you think about it, like Ikea, why couldn't you, for example, sign the European-wide agreement with Ikea? Because in the end, once you've signed up that venue, the mobile operators need to go with you. And you know Vodafone, I guess, from Italy and maybe Spain. So It's not -- I guess, it's more venue-based than kind of built-to-suite, because everyone would want to be in those high-capacity areas at some point.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome to Senior Housing Properties Trust's call covering the third quarter 2016 results. Joining me on today's call are David Hegarty, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Rick Siedel, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer.Today's cal
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome to Senior Housing Properties Trust's call covering the third quarter 2016 results. Joining me on today's call are David Hegarty, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Rick Siedel, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer.
Today's call includes a presentation by management, followed by a question-and-answer session. I would like to note that the transcription, recording and retransmission of today's conference call are strictly prohibited without the prior written consent of Senior Housing.
Today's conference call contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and other securities laws. These forward-looking statements are based upon Senior Housing's present beliefs and expectations as of today, Friday, November 4, 2016. The company undertakes no obligation to revise or publicly release the results of any revision to the forward-looking statements made in today's conference call, other than through filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, or SEC. In addition, this call may contain non-GAAP numbers, including normalized funds from operation, or normalized FFO, and cash-based net operating income, or cash NOI. A reconciliation of these non-GAAP figures to net income and components to calculate AFFO, CAD or FAD are available in our supplemental operating and financial data package found on our website at www.snhreit.com.
Actual results may differ materially from those projected in any forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause those differences is contained in our filings with the SEC. Investors are cautioned not to place undue reliance upon any forward-looking statements.
I would now like to call -- turn the call over to Dave.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brad, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today on our third quarter earnings call. Earlier this morning, we reported normalized funds from operations, or normalized FFO, of $0.45 per share for the third quarter, a decrease
componenttext:
Thank you, Brad, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today on our third quarter earnings call. Earlier this morning, we reported normalized funds from operations, or normalized FFO, of $0.45 per share for the third quarter, a decrease of $0.01 per share year-over-year. This quarter was transitional for SNH as well as the industry as asset dispositions and industry trends negatively impacted the results. However, we expect that these dispositions and recent transitions will improve our portfolio's future results. In the third quarter, we continued to focus on adding value through internal growth, more efficient operations and attractive long-term financing. We believe investors appreciate and support our strategy as confirmed through the performance for our common stock, which has produced a total return of over 55% through the first 3 quarters of this year.
Highlights for the third quarter were that we grew consolidated same-property cash NOI by 2.1% year-over-year. In July, closed on a $620 million attract of a 10-year fixed-rate financing, allowing us to term out a majority of our outstanding volumes under our $1 billion revolving credit facility. We sold 4 medical office buildings and 1 skilled nursing facility for a total of $20.4 million, bringing our year-to-date total dispositions to approximately $30.2 million. We prepaid $92 million of mortgages with a weighted average interest rate of approximately 6% per annum, and subsequent to the quarter-end, prepaid $42.5 million of mortgages at 6.5% per annum. Also, subsequent to quarter-end, we acquired one MOB for $18.5 million bringing our year-to-date total acquisitions to approximately $207 million. In addition, we agreed to acquire 2 private pay senior living communities for $18.6 million, which we believe -- which we expect will close by year-end. We did have some offsetting challenges, which we will discuss during the course of this call.
Our portfolio is comprised of well-diversified, private-pay focused health care real estate, which is designed to benefit from overall health care trends. In the third quarter, approximately 41% of our NOI was attributable to triple net leased senior living communities, 15% to manage senior living communities, 41% to medical office buildings and the remaining 3% to triple net leased to wellness center operators.
In the third quarter, we increased our total portfolio net operating income over the prior year by $2.3 million or 1.4%. This total NOI increase is related mainly to investment activities in each of our portfolio segments. The external growth in the triple net senior living portfolio is primarily result of the sale leaseback transaction to 7 senior living communities in June and was partially reduced by unfortunate defaults resulting in the transition to 2 triple net leased senior living communities to our managed senior living portfolio during the year. The impact of converting these triple net leased assets to managed assets was a decrease in our quarterly NOI of approximately $400,000 year-over-year. However, since the transition, the properties are now turning around and are well on their way to become stabilized and more profitable. In our MOB portfolio, our acquisition and disposition activities resulted in a net increase of $1.2 million in NOI year-over-year.
Now I'd like to discuss our results within each segment. Our triple net leased senior living portfolio continues to perform very well with same-store cash NOI increasing 1.9% year-over-year. The triple net senior living portfolio had a combined occupancy of 85.3% and rent coverage of 1.33x for the 12 months ended June 30, 2016. The coverage ratios of our leases remained strong and very consistent with prior quarters. We've seen occupancy impacted by new competition in certain markets within our lease portfolio. But our tenants responded by controlling products and increasing rates in markets where they can and investing the necessary capital in the communities to remain competitive. We continue to be comfortable with our tenants' ability to cover the rent due to us.
Our managed senior living portfolio same-store cash NOI decreased 2.9% year-over-year. Occupancy declined 60 basis points in the same-store portfolio over the prior year, but with a slight increase in total revenue. Declines in occupancy were more pronounced in the skilled nursing units within our CCRCs, with skilled nursing revenue was down just over $1 million this quarter over the prior year quarter. This is due to trends in Medicare reimbursement and growth of managed care programs, and several skilled nursing units were out of service during the quarter due to refurbishment. In fact, one community, the skilled nursing wing is being completely converted to assisted living and memory care units. We were pleased to see increases in independent assisted living revenues at our buildings, which more than offset the decrease in skilled nursing revenue. This increase demonstrates that our operators continue to push IL and AL rates, where they can, to combat nursing and other operating challenges.
Expenses were up on the same-store basis 1.3% year-over-year, primarily in employee benefit costs, real estate taxes and management fees. We continue to invest capital in and find opportunities to grow our managed senior living communities. Our operators are committed to increasing profitability during this time of increased competition through revenue-generating initiatives, controlling costs, investing in human capital and furthering the programming that makes them the providers of choice in our markets. We are encouraged that we have seen a meaningful increase in senses as we progress into the fourth quarter.
The medical office buildings, or MOB, portfolio remained well occupied this quarter with overall occupancy at the end of the third quarter of 95.9%. Occupancy in the same-store MOB portfolio increased 30 basis points to 96.3%. Same-store cash NOI increased 20 basis points year-over-year as a result of net leasing activity in the quarter, offset by slightly higher year-over-year nonrecoverable expenses.
Turning to our acquisition and disposition activities. Subsequent to quarter-end in October, we acquired one MOB in Ohio, occupied by a publicly traded medical device manufacturer, at an 8.25% cap rate for $18.5 million. And this acquisition brings our total acquisition volume to approximately $207 million year-to-date. We also agreed to acquire 2 private pay senior living communities in Illinois with 126 units for $18.6 million that will be triple net leased at initial rental rate of 7.5%. This acquisition is subject to customary closing conditions, but is expected to close before year-end. In the third quarter, we sold 4 MOBs located in Oklahoma and 1 skilled nursing facility in Wisconsin for a total of $20.4 million. Our year-to-date dispositions' total is now $30.2 million, at an average cap rate of approximately 12%.
At September 30, we had one MOB located in Pennsylvania and one former memory care building at a senior living community located in Florida, classified as held for sale. The intention of our dispositions program is to enhance the overall asset quality of our portfolio and our internal growth potential going forward. While these dispositions will dilute in the short term, they achieved these 2 goals by pruning the portfolio of noncore assets. We continue to monitor the investment opportunities in the senior living and medical office markets and are being disciplined to maximize our risk-adjusted return. Acquisition activity for the foreseeable future will continue to be modest with individual properties and small portfolios, and funding expansion and improvement within our portfolio.
I'd like to now turn it back over to Rick to provide a more detailed discussion of our financial results for the quarter.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. We are pleased with what we were able to accomplish in the quarter to improve the quality of our portfolio and improve our financial position for the utilization of attractively priced long-term financing. These a
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. We are pleased with what we were able to accomplish in the quarter to improve the quality of our portfolio and improve our financial position for the utilization of attractively priced long-term financing. These actions, along with the performance in each of our segments, resulted in normalized FFO of $105.7 million or $0.45 per share, a decrease of 2.2% compared to last year. We also declared a $0.39 per share dividend in October that will be distributed to shareholders on November 17, 2016.
Rental income for the quarter increased $6.6 million or 4.2% from the third quarter of last year to $165.5 million. This increase is primarily due to the acquisitions of 2 medical office buildings and 8 triple net leased senior living communities since July 1, 2015, partially offset by the sale of 5 skilled nursing facilities and 4 MOBs during the same period.
On a same-store basis, rental income increased $3.4 million or 2.2%. This increase was largely attributable to increased escalation income in our MOB portfolio as well as increases in rental income related to funding capital improvements at certain of our communities within our leased senior living portfolio. As a reminder, consistent with recent non-GAAP reporting guidance, we will recognize all the percentage rent related to our triple net leased senior living communities in the fourth quarter for both our GAAP and non-GAAP performance measures.
Residence fees and services revenue from our 68 managed senior living communities increased 2.1% compared to the third quarter of 2015 to $98.5 million. This increase is primarily attributable to our acquisition of one managed senior living community and the 2 transitioned triple net leased properties into this portfolio, along with an increase of 1.1% in our average monthly rent to $4,208. These increases were partially offset by a decrease in occupancy from last year. The decline in occupancy was most pronounced in the skilled nursing units within our CCRCs, resulting in a decrease of over $1 million of revenue year-over-year. This decrease was partially attributable to beds being out of service as we continued to transform the units into higher-margin rehab-to-home units and partially attributable to changes caused by Medicare ACOs or managed care programs.
Property operating expenses from our MOBs and managed senior living communities increased 6.6% in the third quarter to a $103.3 million compared to the same period last year, primarily due to the acquisitions and the transition communities I just mentioned. On a consolidated same-store basis, property operating expenses increased $3.9 million. This increase was primarily attributable to increased employee health benefit costs and real estate taxes in our managed senior living communities and increases in operating expenses in our MOBs, particularly real estate taxes which were largely recoverable from our tenants.
General and administrative expenses increased $1.8 million or 17.4% to $12.1 million this quarter compared to the third quarter of last year, primarily as a result of increases in business management fees and stock-based compensation incurred in Q3 of 2016. Much of these increases are related to changes in the market price of our shares, which was up 53% year-to-date as of September 30, 2016. With G&A at 4.6% of revenues for the quarter, SNH continues to benefit from the efficiencies of our management structure and remains one of the more efficient companies in the health care REIT sector, particularly when considering the size of our portfolio.
We recorded noncash impairment charges totaling $4.6 million in the third quarter of 2016 related to 2 buildings. The first was a skilled nursing facility that was formerly leased to Five Star that was sold during the quarter and the second related to our planned disposition of a former memory care building out of managed senior living community that was classified as held for sale at September 30. We expect proceeds totaling approximately $5 million from the sale of these 2 properties classified as held for sale at the end of the quarter.
Interest expense increased 11.4% to $43.4 million this quarter compared to the third quarter of 2015. The increase was a result of us closing the $620 million, 10-year, interest-only secured financing in July, along with a $200 million term loan closed in September of 2015 and the $250 million 30-year senior notes issued in February of 2016. These increases were partially offset by the repayments of $250 million of our senior notes in November of 2015 and a $168 million of mortgages that had encumbered 6 of our properties at an average interest rate of 5.72% since July 1, 2015. The July financing shared by 2 Class A life science buildings located in Boston's Seaport District allowed us to term out the majority of the outstanding borrowings under our revolving credit facility. At the end of October of 2016, we prepaid another $42.5 million of mortgages that had encumbered 8 more of our properties at an average interest rate of 6.54%. We recognized $659,000 of dividend income from our equity investment in the RMR Group during the quarter. We expect dividend income to run at this amount per quarter going forward for the foreseeable future. In the third quarter, we invested $5.3 million into revenue-producing capital improvements at our triple net leased senior living communities for which we will earn an 8% return on the amount funded.
Our recurring capital expenditures for the third quarter totaled $12.2 million and included $3.8 million that are MOBs for building improvements, $3.9 million on MOB tenant improvements and leasing costs, and $4.5 million at our managed senior living communities. We also spent $7.4 million on development and redevelopment capital projects, with a vast majority of it being spent at our managed senior living communities. These projects include major renovations intended to reposition the property in its market or give our communities a competitive advantage against new supply that we see entering the market. At September 30, 2016, we had $40.8 million of cash on hand and $785 million available on our $1 billion revolver.
Our total debt to gross assets at the end of the third quarter was 42.9%, and debt to adjusted EBITDA was 6.0x on a trailing 12-month basis. We are comfortable with our leverage ratios where they are given the quality of our portfolio and the significant amount of liquidity we have available to us.
I will now turn the call back over to our operator to open it up for questions.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Just looking at your triple net coverage ratios that you gave on Page 32 of your stack. Just quickly, are those EBITDAR or EBITDARM coverage levels? And if you could provide the 4 different Five Star ones that you used to disclose?

componenttextpreview: The -- those are on an EBITDARM basis and probably the reasoning for that is the fact that the management fees sometimes using 5% is the rule of thumb that people often use, but many times, you know, the real cost of managing might be 2%, 3%, 4%. But...
componenttext: The -- those are on an EBITDARM basis and probably the reasoning for that is the fact that the management fees sometimes using 5% is the rule of thumb that people often use, but many times, you know, the real cost of managing might be 2%, 3%, 4%. But...

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I can speak to the change in disclosure and not breaking it out. I think it's important to remember that Five Star leases all have cross default provisions, there's corporate guarantee in place. They're all backstopped by the real estate that Five St
componenttext: Yes. I can speak to the change in disclosure and not breaking it out. I think it's important to remember that Five Star leases all have cross default provisions, there's corporate guarantee in place. They're all backstopped by the real estate that Five Star owns and operates on its own account. So we really think about it as consolidated coverage, which is the same way we think about Sunrise, which also has 4 leases with us. So this quarter, we would've had to added -- we would've had to add a fifth line for that new master lease for the leaseback transaction we just did. And it would've only had 2 days of activity in it. It just didn't make a lot of sense. So we sat back and said, "Okay, we should just simplify this presentation and report it as a consolidated number." It's more meaningful to us that way, and we don't really think breaking up the detail added much to users of our financial statements either. I don't have the detail in front of me, but I can say -- I mean, the number just ticked up a little bit on a consolidated basis. I don't think any of the leases moved significantly. I think had we presented in detail, the fifth lease would've looked a little funny because it was 2 days of prorated activity. But overall, we're still comfortable with Five Star's coverage where it is at 1.23x.

componenttext: Well, in all of our leases, the -- we have a mechanism where we can fund the CapEx if they wish us to and so -- like, in fact, we fund most of their long-term capital items. So within our typical underwriting, like we are spending about $1,500 -- between $1,200 and $1,500 a unit on our private pay senior living. Most underwriting would assume anywhere from $750 to $1,500. But I think we wouldn't push it on the tenant, and we use our own estimates. Depending on the profitability.

componenttext: We do. Generally where they come to us is for the more improvement-type projects that will enhance the community and last longer term.

componenttext: They are. The tenants fund all the maintenance CapEx. And we're happy to invest further in our communities, make sure the work gets done and generate a return on that investment.

componenttextpreview: I think we've definitely seen the impact of new supply. We've already seen new openings within 5 miles at about 18% of our communities this past year. The NIC data covers the majority but all of our markets and when we scrub the NIC data, we do see some n
componenttext: I think we've definitely seen the impact of new supply. We've already seen new openings within 5 miles at about 18% of our communities this past year. The NIC data covers the majority but all of our markets and when we scrub the NIC data, we do see some new construction in the pipeline, but we do believe it will be manageable. The NIC data tells us that about 33% of our communities have new supply, both new construction together with openings in the past 12 months. So we are hopeful that we've already seen the majority of the new competition, but believe it will be manageable on a go-forward basis.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean to add to -- I was just going to say big picture, looking at this quarterly results, one thing that jumped out at us, and we've tried to make the point in our presentation was the fact that we have a number of properties that have full services, fu
componenttext: I mean to add to -- I was just going to say big picture, looking at this quarterly results, one thing that jumped out at us, and we've tried to make the point in our presentation was the fact that we have a number of properties that have full services, full CCRC services with IL, AL and skilled nursing unit typically. And what we -- this quarter, we had a drop in revenue of over a $1 million in Medicare A inpatient revenue, primarily from those types of communities. I said some of it is due to new refurbishments going on at a number of communities but also at significant pace, particularly in Florida, is lost revenue due to managed care programs. So really the private pay senior living side has actually done very well during this quarter. And as we mentioned in Q4 to date, we are seeing a noticeable improvement in senses. So a number of programs that have been implemented over the last couple of quarters, we believe, are bearing fruit, and I'd say our properties are doing, on the senior living side, pretty well.

componenttext: No, 18% has already seen new supply when we look at the data and look at the new openings within the past 12 months. 18% of our communities already have -- that's based -- that's baked into our current numbers. componenttextpreview: I think we definitely did see increased operating expenses this quarter. We mentioned in our prepared remarks that real estate taxes impacted both senior living and our MOB portfolio. Real estate taxes in total were up about $2 million year-over-year, and
componenttext: I think we definitely did see increased operating expenses this quarter. We mentioned in our prepared remarks that real estate taxes impacted both senior living and our MOB portfolio. Real estate taxes in total were up about $2 million year-over-year, and a lot of it on the MOB side is recoverable, but unmanaged side, one other things we noticed is that the timing of our real estate tax appeals tends to move the needle on -- talking about a portfolio of 65 assets. We also, in the managed senior living business, saw increased health benefits costs this quarter, largely a function of a small number of extraordinarily high individual claims that wind up increasing overall costs beyond what we normally see. These costs were up about $800,000 this quarter compared to last year. So to your point, I mean the operators did a great job offsetting a lot of it through labor efficiencies and trying to manage overtime through the vacation season, but definitely had an impact on our results. On a go-forward basis, I don't think we see a ton of structural changes. I think -- you know the more you focus on managing labor and focusing on supply chain efforts, the more momentum that effort gets and I think, it will continue and become cultural, and we are hopeful to continue to see savings and growth and NOI there. But I think, we've generally talked about targets of 3% to 5% growth in the managed business and think that's probably still appropriate. But again, there certainly has been some headwinds with both competition and, again, a couple of these unique operating expense issues.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in your market, as you look at the impacts of supply, both on the net lease side and the managed side, just based on what you're seeing in terms of new construction, any sense of when you could see all that hit as actual inventory and the source
componenttext: And then in your market, as you look at the impacts of supply, both on the net lease side and the managed side, just based on what you're seeing in terms of new construction, any sense of when you could see all that hit as actual inventory and the source of competition?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean I'm encouraged that we've already seen it -- openings already at 18% of our buildings. So our current numbers already reflect some of those that new supply where the units are open and the operators are actively trying to fill them up. So there is
componenttext: I mean I'm encouraged that we've already seen it -- openings already at 18% of our buildings. So our current numbers already reflect some of those that new supply where the units are open and the operators are actively trying to fill them up. So there is certainly more coming, we are aware of that, but believe it will be manageable.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just last one. On the portfolio, you have seen some of your peers -- we've seen some large transformative transactions, and we've seen a lot of different buyers come to the table. Any sense of what -- are you looking at the portfolio
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just last one. On the portfolio, you have seen some of your peers -- we've seen some large transformative transactions, and we've seen a lot of different buyers come to the table. Any sense of what -- are you looking at the portfolio now today given where the pricing is and the buyers we've seen? Any sense -- any culling that you could do to improve your overall metric?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the -- we are selling off some selected assets over the course of time. I don't -- in the near term, I don't see like a major shift like some of the peers have done some major repositioning of their whole portfolio. I don't see us doing that
componenttext: Well, I think the -- we are selling off some selected assets over the course of time. I don't -- in the near term, I don't see like a major shift like some of the peers have done some major repositioning of their whole portfolio. I don't see us doing that in a major way, but I think individual assets can we -- periodically sell down our SNF positions and few underperforming properties. On the MOB side, again, a number of the transactions being done in the marketplace are being done at cap rates in the 5s and 6 -- low 6s, and we realized that that's not a price range that we can compete in at the moment. And so, I think we -- looking at other selective situations that make a lot of sense for us. And so that's why I think our acquisition path will be modest and, again, thus we don't need a tremendous amount of capital at the moment. And we've frankly done our best when we've kind of stayed out of the hot markets and gone in when there is a hiccup in the economy or the market, and we have capital available to go in and take advantage of that. So, again, we are trying to exercise discipline and more rush down sidelines, but be somewhat in the ballgame.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So, I mean, looking at Five Star's actual financials, they have had negative operating cash flow for the 9 months this year. How should we think about their ability to still pay your rent and how this ultimately ends up? I mean, are -- is there a re
componenttext: Okay. So, I mean, looking at Five Star's actual financials, they have had negative operating cash flow for the 9 months this year. How should we think about their ability to still pay your rent and how this ultimately ends up? I mean, are -- is there a rent cut that needs to happen here to help out Five Star? Because it seems like the only other option Five Star has would be to sell real estate that they own to help their cash flow and yet -- that's been prevented, it looks like, in this -- and tied to this activist campaign against Five Star right now.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well Five Star is going through a transition period and one other things that, as I mentioned, for us, the Medicare A impact of a $1 million to us x 4, it's $4 million a year. If you extrapolate that on to Five Stars somewhat, they have to change their bu
componenttext: Well Five Star is going through a transition period and one other things that, as I mentioned, for us, the Medicare A impact of a $1 million to us x 4, it's $4 million a year. If you extrapolate that on to Five Stars somewhat, they have to change their business strategy to minimize the Medicare business and focus more on the private pay to expand that. They are transitioning. They did have a rough quarter this quarter, but I think there are a lot of positive things that over time will get them back to cash flow positive on a regular basis. But, as you said, they currently sit on about $50 million of cash and have a completely available revolving credit facility of another $100 million, and they own about 26 properties, I believe, on their balance sheet. I don't -- I mean if they want to sell some assets here and there, that's their choice, but I think the whole -- it's their choice anyway. So we are comfortable that they need some time to work through this stuff, but they should be okay.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just I mean where is -- is there an actual default threshold on the leases?

componenttextpreview: Not a covenant as a level of performance. Also to -- when you delve into the detail, I think if you took out, say, the bottom 3% or 5% of their portfolio and close them, sell them, whatever their coverage ratios would materially improve. So it's up to the
componenttext: Not a covenant as a level of performance. Also to -- when you delve into the detail, I think if you took out, say, the bottom 3% or 5% of their portfolio and close them, sell them, whatever their coverage ratios would materially improve. So it's up to them to determine when to sell those properties to do something with them and they need our consent, obviously, but we'll likely consent to something like that. So I think they could improve their results by eliminating some of their problem properties.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to understand this loss of revenue from the Medicare Part A side. Again, your skilled nursing, when we take a look at your portfolio, it's still -- it's such a small piece of your portfolio. I guess I'm just surprised about the magnitude o
componenttext: I'm just trying to understand this loss of revenue from the Medicare Part A side. Again, your skilled nursing, when we take a look at your portfolio, it's still -- it's such a small piece of your portfolio. I guess I'm just surprised about the magnitude of that number. So I'm really trying to understand what's going on there.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. It's -- it has happened pretty quickly and what is happening is, in the stand-alone skilled nursing facilities, the properties we own are more your traditional long-term care nursing homes that typically have a fair amount of Medicaid and very litt
componenttext: Right. It's -- it has happened pretty quickly and what is happening is, in the stand-alone skilled nursing facilities, the properties we own are more your traditional long-term care nursing homes that typically have a fair amount of Medicaid and very little Medicare, little private pay. So I think they're pretty much like stable operations generally, but within the CCRC properties we have, there is often 40 to 50 beds that are for skilled nursing and normally those have been shorter term rehab stays or could be a little bit longer-term, but what's happened is particularly in the state of Florida, a lot of the managed care programs are now directing people to go straight to the home and skipping the skilled nursing, and maybe having some home health care to follow up. But -- so that has really bypassed a lot of the rehab units that we have within our CCRCs. So -- what's happening is we are making some changes as far as developing the relationships and having better electronic medical records, which then could be provided to a level of systems to try to draw in more referrals and things like that as well as referrals outside [indiscernible]. I was going to say we probably have 100 units across the system that are just out of commission because of refurbishments.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Now, I understand why I'm not seeing it. Okay, that's helpful. So that's number one. Then number 2, you talked a little bit about G&A that part of it was impacted by your stock price doing so well this year. I think I'm curious is that because you j
componenttext: Okay. Now, I understand why I'm not seeing it. Okay, that's helpful. So that's number one. Then number 2, you talked a little bit about G&A that part of it was impacted by your stock price doing so well this year. I think I'm curious is that because you just had to do more higher incentive pay? Or is it tied back to the management fees that RMR gets paid? I'm just kind of curious like what's that -- what that increase that tied to the increase in your share value?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a little bit of both. So we -- as you know, our business management fees are based on the lower of historical cost or market cap. And as a result, we actually paid a lower fee based on market cap from the third quarter of 2015 through Q2 of 2016. So,
componenttext: It's a little bit of both. So we -- as you know, our business management fees are based on the lower of historical cost or market cap. And as a result, we actually paid a lower fee based on market cap from the third quarter of 2015 through Q2 of 2016. So, year-to-date or through September 30, our stock was up 53%. So we've now switched back to paying fees based on historical costs, which has an increase in our G&A. Also because of our management structure, our share based comp is predominantly issued to nonemployees because they are employees of RMR. And as a result of issuing shares to nonemployees, we actually recognize expense based on the vesting date share value, not the grant date share value, like most companied would. So as our stock price increased, so did our comp expense. So -- I think, it's on page 14 of our supplemental, you'll see a fairly sizable increase in our noncash stock comp expense.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then, again, just back to Five Star and some of the comments [indiscernible] made earlier on, again, when you see the company generating $5 million of EBITDA a quarter, but yet they have a CapEx budget each year like $40 million.
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then, again, just back to Five Star and some of the comments [indiscernible] made earlier on, again, when you see the company generating $5 million of EBITDA a quarter, but yet they have a CapEx budget each year like $40 million. I'm just kind of curious again -- they're trying to make all these efforts to improve fundamentals, but are they kind of forced to suddenly defer CapEx, which, in my mind, would put their assets at a competitive disadvantage in several markets where there is increasing supply. Like I'm just trying to wonder when you kind of talk to them. How do you kind of try to manage those 2 dynamics? They will try to conserve cash, but at the same time to trying to be offensive to kind of stave off some of the increased competition?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: They are spending a significant amount of capital, and they are full steam ahead. I don't think they're holding back on any capital. So they have to do it to, obviously, compete against the new product that is coming online. Good amount of it is capital t
componenttext: They are spending a significant amount of capital, and they are full steam ahead. I don't think they're holding back on any capital. So they have to do it to, obviously, compete against the new product that is coming online. Good amount of it is capital that would be financed through us. So we're -- it's not coming out of their pocket per se, but it is being financed at an 8% rate. And then what's also interesting is that lot of properties where there is significant capital being spent on it, then you can turn to your residence and demonstrate that you spent the money, now we can -- we're going to raise your rates by 5%, 6%, 7%. And it goes down a lot easier and in fact, we often find that [ chances ] increases during the major construction project because people become involved in what's going on in the community and they like seeing it and it's -- it actually benefits the community to see the construction going on.

componenttext: Right. No -- I mean these major projects that we are aware of are -- we expect to get through, and I think they're, as I said, through a transition period right now. And I think it will benefit them in the longer term.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my first couple questions are on the MOB side. You experienced pretty favorable rental rate on renewals at $37. Any color there? Any specific things you can point to? And -- or is this a mix of gross leases and triple net?
componenttext: I guess my first couple questions are on the MOB side. You experienced pretty favorable rental rate on renewals at $37. Any color there? Any specific things you can point to? And -- or is this a mix of gross leases and triple net?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Yes, the new leases -- I mean, certainly, we have constant rollover at the Cedars-Sinai towers there and renewals today are in the $76 to $78 a foot range. And I think, in general, we are experiencing very positive rent rollovers. What we do have t
componenttext: Right. Yes, the new leases -- I mean, certainly, we have constant rollover at the Cedars-Sinai towers there and renewals today are in the $76 to $78 a foot range. And I think, in general, we are experiencing very positive rent rollovers. What we do have that is also impacting our numbers is the fact that we do have a couple of properties that are still in a free-rent period that we would expect to burn off before year-end and that would help us beginning 2017 in January. But other than that -- I mean, I don't -- I think just the blended average has really pushed that rental rate up.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then any color on re-leasing spreads whether it's -- you want to highlight Cedars-Sinai or just the portfolio in general?
componenttext: And then any color on re-leasing spreads whether it's -- you want to highlight Cedars-Sinai or just the portfolio in general?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say in general it's -- during this particular quarter, I think it's been flat. We have had some good -- very good progress out there in California and a few other markets. But, I know I think we've experienced some issues in rolling over rents in
componenttext: I would say in general it's -- during this particular quarter, I think it's been flat. We have had some good -- very good progress out there in California and a few other markets. But, I know I think we've experienced some issues in rolling over rents in upstate New York or Albuquerque, which offset that. That's why we say in the aggregate, unfortunately, as a net, but we have been seeing 3 to -- generally 3% to 5% [indiscernible].

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Rick, you mentioned property tax increases on the MOBs and your ability to recover some of that. Is there a general rule of thumb or how much do you actually recover, maybe on a percentage basis from tenants?
componenttext: And Rick, you mentioned property tax increases on the MOBs and your ability to recover some of that. Is there a general rule of thumb or how much do you actually recover, maybe on a percentage basis from tenants?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have it in front of me. It's a pretty high percentage. I think we were -- I think we were largely able to recover most of it from what we saw this quarter. But it's a high percentage and it does impact -- the structure of our leases does impact a
componenttext: I don't have it in front of me. It's a pretty high percentage. I think we were -- I think we were largely able to recover most of it from what we saw this quarter. But it's a high percentage and it does impact -- the structure of our leases does impact a little bit. We do occasionally have to wait until base year resets or something like that, but I guess you can probably go 80-plus percent on drop through or recovery.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then I think there was a previous question and Dave, you addressed it sort of, I guess. When you are looking at Vertex, and I guess there is a possible candidate to sell into a JV, why is that on the table? I guess I would consider it one of you
componenttext: Okay, and then I think there was a previous question and Dave, you addressed it sort of, I guess. When you are looking at Vertex, and I guess there is a possible candidate to sell into a JV, why is that on the table? I guess I would consider it one of your premier assets. Why not look across the portfolio, particularly, with Five Star exposure, where you could reduce there, maybe that would help lowering concentration, help your valuation to ultimately tap the equity market.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you know, I think with the Vertex property, our intent is to diversify our risk. We've already encumbered it with debt, so we should realize some of the value within that property. And then also to some degree, it hurts us in the sense that it is --
componenttext: Well, you know, I think with the Vertex property, our intent is to diversify our risk. We've already encumbered it with debt, so we should realize some of the value within that property. And then also to some degree, it hurts us in the sense that it is -- the rent there is flat for 5 years, then there is a significant bump of about 10% and so, it definitely hurts us, thanks to our growth story. But with regards to the senior housing side and -- frankly, we have seen very little interest on our side from JV potential partners, I mean we're pleased to see that some of our peers have broken through that and enticed some parties. So that might be in our future down the road. At this point, we have not found receptive parties to that side.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, Head of the Investor Relations at Cellnex. I'm joined today by Alex Mestre, International Business Development Director; and Jos Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director, and who will lead today's presentation. I
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. My name is Juan Gaitan, Head of the Investor Relations at Cellnex. I'm joined today by Alex Mestre, International Business Development Director; and Jos Manuel Aisa, CFO and M&A Director, and who will lead today's presentation. I would like to thank you for joining us today for Cellnex H1 2016 Results Conference Call. We have, earlier today, posted a presentation, which we will refer to throughout our prepared remarks under the Investor Relations section on our website. And then we'll open the line for a Q&A session.
So now I'll hand over to Jos Manuel. Please, Jos Manuel.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you so much for your time today. And please allow me to start by highlighting the main milestones of the period. We are in Page 4. Here, you can see that today, we're presenting again a solid set of results that confirm the market ex
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you so much for your time today. And please allow me to start by highlighting the main milestones of the period. We are in Page 4. Here, you can see that today, we're presenting again a solid set of results that confirm the market expectations for the period. We have also resume our M&A activity by executing 2 value-accretive deals, while establishing our presence in very dynamic markets. We are best positioned candidate to consolidate the European tower landscape. We're also taking the first steps to become the European leader in the distributed antenna systems sector.
From operations perspective, our efficiency plan is on track, while we have also recovered TV revenues we lost in the past. And finally, we are glad to announce that Cellnex has been included in the IBEX 35 Index.
Moving now to Slide 5. In terms of activities, we have managed to increase the number of PoPs by 2% compared to December 2015. We are also paving the way to boost our presence in the DAS business by acquiring CommsCon. CommsCon provides today DAS services in 83 locations in Italy and is analyzing many additional projects in environments where an important demand for mobile data is seen. We continue to assess the possibility to invest in fiber backhauling to the tower for our customers, and we are making good progress on this front. We're closely monitoring and proactively analyzing potential new opportunities that might arise from the consolidation of the fourth mobile operator role across Europe.
Finally, we continue to pursue rationalization projects with mobile operators, and we are working hard to reach an agreement in the short term.
Regarding broadcasting, we can confirm that the retendering process of the 6 new TV channels have successfully been completed with all Chinese broadcasting and generating earnings from April, thus, providing a stable revenue release, going forward.
Regarding the network services and others, we continue to see a solid performance, faster connectivity and emergency communications businesses. It is important to highlight that we -- that when we enter any country, we pursue new services levering on our Telecom Site Rental activity.
Finally, we keep analyzing any single opportunity at hand to continue creating value for our shareholders. And one such opportunity is our efficiency program, on which we are making good progress according to the timing I [ really ] share with you.
Turning to Slide 6. You can see here the evolution of PoPs and our resulting consolidated tenancy ratio, with increases being explained by consistent organic growth rates. We have managed to add more than 400 PoPs in the period reaching a tenancy ratio of 1.56, a 4% increase when compared to June 2015 and a 2% increase when compared to December 2015.
On the next chart, you can find a comprehensive explanation of the performance of revenues in the Telecom Site Rental business. You can see how the shifting asset base contributes EUR 4 million to our consolidated figures, while the change of perimeter adds EUR 54 million in this period.
When we've not adjusted EBITDA, you can see how the negative impact of the DTT single cut that took place in 2015, which was a one-off positive effect, is more than offset by the switch on our new TV channels, the change of perimeter and the contribution of organic growth, which represent EUR 4 million in the period.
Let me now explain in detail on Slide 7, our recurring levered free cash flow generation in the period. I would like to start by highlighting that the cash conversion ratio of EBITDA into current level free cash flow in the period has been 94%, with current cash flow increasing by 24%.
Looking now to revenues. Telecom Site Rental increases mainly due to our strong organic growth and acquisitions. The broadcasting business reflects now the new TV channels from April when compared to the previous quarter. And network services and other continue showing a solid performance, mainly due to a high activity in the connectivity business.
Moving to OpEx. We have a very well-contained cost base with a flat performance on a like-for-like basis. The increase is mainly due to cost directly associated with our recent transactions. Our adjusted EBITDA reached EUR 134 million, in line with our guidance for the full year, and showing a strong 17% increase when compared to last year.
Maintenance CapEx is well below our 3% guidance for the year, due to a time effect and is expected to catch up within this year to reach a more normalized level.
Our working capital change is neutral for the period, thanks to our strict management, and in line with our full year guidance.
Interest paid reflect our current capital structure with the first coupon associated with our bond paid this week, therefore, to be considered for the next quarter. And tax paid reflect the implementation of tax management measure as well as the tax payment scheduled in the year.
Non-M&A expansion CapEx include the first step of our efficiency program with EUR 12 million associated with cash advances in the context or the renegotiation of our leases.
Moving now to our balance sheet on Slide 8. Cellnex leverage has decreased to 3.3x net debt annualized EBITDA, well below our long-term objective of 4x. Our total net debt is EUR 872 million, with our bond accounting for most of the debt. We're now setting the change in net debt and is needs to be taken into account. That in general, we paid the second tranche of Volta Extended phase 2. And in June, we paid acquisition of CommsCon. You will find all these details in the Excel sheet that is in our website. 
We have also paid our final dividend in July, bringing the total distribution to around EUR 20 million, approximately 20% of the recurring levered free cash flow generated in the second half of 2015, in accordance with our dividend policy.
Coming back to the remaining lines of our income statement, depreciation and amortization credits increased mainly as a result of our recent acquisitions. And interest expense increased in line with our capital structure.
Moving to Slide 9. You can see on the left-hand side our capital structure, with near liquidity lines having been signed at a very competitive cost of around 1%, alone for new upcoming growth opportunities.
On the right-hand side, you can see also our debt maturities profile compared to our cash flow generation in a cumulative basis. We can, therefore, in summary, say that we face no refinancing risk due to the long-term [indiscernible] of our debt and our cash flow generation capacity. We have improved our liquidity position. And we have a solid credit rating with our Standard & Poor's outlook having been improved recently. On that, our recent acquisition have been financed at a very low marginal cost.
So now regarding the M&A update. Given our high M&A activity, during the last weeks, we believe it is worth offering a brief recap of our last year's and also provide some additional background on how these transactions fit into our equity story. 
If we now move to Slide 11. You can see a summary of our recent activity. 251 towers in Holland. An agreement with Bouygues to buy up to 500 towers in France and acquisition of Commscon in Italy. These deals represent the first step into very dynamic market. They allow us to diversify into countries with a strong credit rating. Hopefully, next, the right platform from which continue to assess and [indiscernible] consolidation opportunities, and therefore, confirm the delivery on our equity story.
On Slide 12, you can see a picture of a new Cellnex perimeter as a result of the recent transactions. More markets, more diversified client base, more focused portfolio on Telecom Site Rental revenues. All-in-all, we can clearly state that after these appreciations, our business risk profile has improved.
Moving to Slide 13. You can see here a table that shows how to think about capital generation from our recent acquisition. The cash conversion ratio from EBITDA into recurrent levered free cash flow is 85%. So I think this figure is very, very high. The new deals are expected to generate EUR 12 million on a full year basis in terms of recurring levered free cash flow. This represents around 10% of the recurring cash flow generated in the first semester 2016, and all this has been achieved always by applying our strict investment criteria.
So now if we assess the different opportunities one after the other, first of all, on Slide 14, you can see a more detailed assessment of our DAS deal that we closed the first day of July. The main idea I would like to highlight is that we are entering a new market with a strong anchor tenant, providing with revenues visibility, and we follow on opportunities that should come in the next quarter. 
Also, there are other characteristics of this deal, such as the high proportion of revenues guaranteed with new clients, in this case, KPN, until 2017, 2018. The tariff scheme, which is in Brexit to CPI having a flow at 0%.
And finally, I would like to say that 20% of the sites that we've acquired overlaps with existing networks of our operators.
On the Slide 16 -- sorry, 15. Here, we present the French opportunity, and this project is an industrial project that sets the foundation for a long-term partnership with a key European player, like Bouygues. One example of this future cooperation is our preemptive right to build up to 250 sites for our anchor tenant. It is important to highlight that this acquisition, unlike the Dutch one, consist on the acquisition of assets of towers. Also, there are other characteristics that make this opportunity unique, such as a very long-term contract of 20 years and also a 2% annual fix fee escalator.
Moving now to Italy on Slide 16. The acquisition of CommsCon represents the opportunity for Cellnex to become the DAS benchmark in Europe. We believe the DAS market has a huge potential and will position Cellnex in the future DAS sector as it is developed. This acquisition provides us with a first-mover advantage and the knowhow required to achieve this leadership. We do really think that CommsCon is a unique platform to capture what we think will be a very significant market in the next years.
At the end of the day, CommsCon will help us to cover -- or to improve the coverage that we can provide from our infrastructures.
Finally, on Slide 17, we present what we call the domino effect, the strategy that we have been implementing for our European expansion. Our intention is to continue acquiring small portfolios in new countries so that we can increase our understanding of the market, build a strong relationship with the aim to continue consolidated [indiscernible] market by pursuing new opportunities. This is what we have successfully done in the past, and is a path that we would follow in order to become the European consolidator.
In Slide 19, just some closing remarks. We are presenting today a solid set of results. We are happy to deliver our equity story, not only from a revenue perspective but also from M&A activity. We continued to be place very well position to consolidate the European tower landscape. We are taking the first step to become the European leader in the new technologies at a step-by-step far more important like the DAS. Current operations are strong, and our efficiency plan is on track. And finally, Cellnex has been included in the IBEX 35. It has already improved the visibility, the liquidity and attractiveness of our store, as you can see in Page 20.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Three questions from my side. First one on M&A. You could comment a bit on what your intentions are in France and Holland after your first acquisitions? What is your view, the critical portfolio size, you would like to achieve? And if you could give a bit
componenttext: Three questions from my side. First one on M&A. You could comment a bit on what your intentions are in France and Holland after your first acquisitions? What is your view, the critical portfolio size, you would like to achieve? And if you could give a bit of guidance on time frame you think you will need to achieve the optimal portfolio size? And then maybe something on an update on the Hutchison portfolio in Italy? That's first question. Second, an OpEx, I understand you could roughly save EUR 50 million from these negotiations over the next 3 to 4 years. Now my question is, how much of that amount do you expect to achieve this year? Then last question on the Russian [ evasion ] process, and 2,000 towers decommissioning you guided to during full year results. Could you give some update on that?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. Thank you very much. Regarding your first question, which was France, Holland and the next steps and time frame. In fact, I think in page -- in the annex in Page 22, you can find the market description of the Netherlands and France. And y
componenttext:
Okay, thank you. Thank you very much. Regarding your first question, which was France, Holland and the next steps and time frame. In fact, I think in page -- in the annex in Page 22, you can find the market description of the Netherlands and France. And you can see how, for instance, in the Netherlands, there are different tower costs. And there's a footnote that is displaying which tower cost there are there. So we are talking at least 1,200 towers from Tower Company. And on top of that, there are other MNOs that have already, let's say, 13,000 towers. We will think that the market is moving, and there will be some angle to consolidate in the next quarter.
Again, the question is always execution versus value criterion. We have to give you an answer regarding when it is very important to understand the criteria's requirement. So it's not easy to tell you. The thing is, we are working on that. We are monitoring this market pretty closely. Also, the French market, French market, again, in Page 22, you can see that there are different MNOs with, let's say, around 50,000 towers. And some TowerCos with 10,000 towers. You all know and it is market -- it is public information that some of these TowerCos potentially may be on sale in the next quarter in competitive process from a public perspective, we can say that, at least. There will be one opportunity in France, hopefully. Your second question was regarding the OpEx. In fact, you were asking about the capital bonds program that we have. First of all, let me tell you that the capital bonds program is working as expected. And we're pretty sure we can get this EUR 15 million by 2019, I think, it was the target. This year, I think that if we go on investing as we are investing around EUR 3 million, EUR 2 million, let's say, EUR 2 million or EUR 3 million depending the timing effect can be obtained. Please be aware that this is, if you invest 1 year, for instance, EUR 20 million in cash advance, it's not the same investing this EUR 20 million at first day of the year or the last date of the year. So it depends. At this time frame have an impact on 2015 numbers. However, all these transactions always follow our very strict criteria. So the payback will there, if not this year, next year. Finally, regarding the consolidation of the market, the 2,000 towers [indiscernible] this month, again, same message as previous quarters. I think we are working a lot and I'm pretty sure that we will present to you an interesting deal. The thing is that each day longer than expected, to be honest. However, it is taking longer because also I don't think that Cellnex is opening this market and providing very good ideas and new angles that have to be explored. Pretty sure that we will come out one day to the market with something positive. Or at least you will see quarter-by-quarter that the number of towers change, and therefore, the PoPs grow, right?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Giles Thorne from Jefferies.
componenttext: Next question is from Giles Thorne from Jefferies.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had 3 questions, please. Starting in Italy, as we consider the implications of Italian MNO consolidation, it would be good to progress the debate from the organic growth opportunities of new entrants to now better understanding, in your view, what your
componenttext: I had 3 questions, please. Starting in Italy, as we consider the implications of Italian MNO consolidation, it would be good to progress the debate from the organic growth opportunities of new entrants to now better understanding, in your view, what your P&L is, as an industrial partner as Iliad relative to your competition in Italy? And staying in Italy, I really have an extension of the previous question. As we look at the accelerated investments announced earlier this week by Inwit, it's clear that TI is probably now not a seller of that state, so given M&A is off the table and also given Inwit is investing to drive growth, do you have any reason to change your capital allocation in Italy? And lastly, on spectrum, at the end of May, we saw the GSMA again pushed for a more aggressive time line for the reconsideration of the sub-700 megahertz band for alternative uses. It'd be interesting to hear your perspective on this development? And how this shift is debated at all for the outlook, for DTT in the sub-700 megahertz band, if at all?

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you Giles for your questions. Let me split your questions into parts, 1 and 2 will be answered by myself, and the third one I will invite Alex Mestre, who is the International Director to answer to your question in the GSM 700 megahertz. Giles, I th
componenttext: Thank you Giles for your questions. Let me split your questions into parts, 1 and 2 will be answered by myself, and the third one I will invite Alex Mestre, who is the International Director to answer to your question in the GSM 700 megahertz. Giles, I think, your first and second question, I think both come at the same time. We are not going to change our plan because of our peer is changing their CapEx plan. I mean, we will have to go on working, following our internal targets with a criteria we have in order to create value for our shareholders. We think that the Italian market, from my perspective, presents a lot of opportunities, one of them being the fourth operator. Obviously, Cellnex is keeping twice on this process, and I think we have the open to assess with different candidates in this opportunity. I think that Cellnex is very well positioned. Cellnex has, let's say, a tenancy ratio in Italy which is 1.2x. So it gives us headroom to grow, give us headroom to put more tenants into our towers as a place now that Italy presents a very demanding electromagnetic revolution. So in this case, having a low tenancy ratio is helpful to grow, is helpful to offer new PoPs. And second, also, I don't think that we are very well positioned to play a key role in this fourth operator and process because we are neutral operator. We are independent tower company, so we do not have any MNO on our shareholding base, and therefore, it will give us headroom, will give us flexibility to treat all our customers in the same way with the same criteria. So I do think that Cellnex is doing -- working -- doing good progress, but always on a very confidential basis and on a very prudent basis, step-by-step. I don't know if Alex Mestre, you can help me to answer the third question.

headline: Cellnex Telecom, S.A., H1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Jos Manuel. On relation to the spectrum, I think it's true that the 700 megahertz is something that the World Radio Conference is also [indiscernible] that at certain point in time, it is required to do a reallocation of the usage of the band.
componenttext: Yes, sure, Jos Manuel. On relation to the spectrum, I think it's true that the 700 megahertz is something that the World Radio Conference is also [indiscernible] that at certain point in time, it is required to do a reallocation of the usage of the band. Remember, like remember, we have the 800 megahertz has already been cleared and now is being used for 4G. Also, I would like to emphasize the concept of the lower the frequencies, the longer the range. So I believe that when an MNO is looking for identification, using -- traveling more kind of a small cells, more microcells, more DAS that Jos Manuel has been explaining in one of the trends as of now. Those frequencies are less interesting because the coverage is much wider than higher frequency. So in relation, identification in the lower frequencies are not as useful as the higher frequencies. In relation to the 700 megahertz, it is clear that the number of stages in Europe have to prepare their clients. This is something that will occur during -- in 2017. Some of the countries have an accelerated plan in relation to that, but when research that in countries like Spain, and as a result also of the latest, let's say, prepositions which is having, in Europe, we understood that it is not going to happen before 2022. And it is the period that has been the frequency rate possible, also within 2020, 2022. And, importantly, during that process and that time, until then, the broadcasting terminologies that will evolve, is able to do an evolution. It will be maybe [indiscernible] visibility to higher compression mechanisms that will keep the overall offer of channels, even migrating them to high definition, very equal as we have today. So in that sense, we expect that in those countries, specifically in Spain, where we have the broadcasting presence as of today, we will remain with a similar offer in terms of digital [indiscernible] than rest of the channels.

Let's remember that the process has yet to be cleared, in terms of the [indiscernible] by European competition authorities. It is intended to happen beginning of September. From that point onwards, what is expected is that the final candidate [indiscernible] will be the one finally getting into the agreement -- with the new merged entity. It is true having other candidates. We've been having discussions logically with all of them. And our value proposition has been, we understand, properly understood, especially in relation to what Jos Manuel was saying that the low tenancy ratio, in that case, where we are now, it is an advantage because it allows us, let's say, to fit very quickly and in a very big amount of number of sites and new mobile network operator.
